petitioners' committee does not file notice of intention to amend it or if an
amended petition has been certified insufficient, the committee may, within two
(2) days after receiving the copy of such certificate, file a request that it
be reviewed by the Council. The Council shall review the certificate at its
next meeting following the filing of such request and approve or disapprove it,
and the Council's determination shall then be a final determination as to the
sufficiency of the petition.
   (c)   Court Review; New Petition. A final determination as to the
sufficiency of a petition shall be subject to court review. A final
determination of insufficiency, even if sustained upon court review, shall not
prejudice the filing of a new petition for the same purpose. (Enacted 11-3-70)
SECTION 15.05   REFERENDUM PETITIONS; SUSPENSION OF EFFECT OF ORDINANCE.
   When a referendum petition is filed with the Clerk of Council, the ordinance
sought to be reconsidered shall be suspended from taking effect. Such
suspension shall terminate when:
      (1)   There is a final determination of insufficiency of the petition; or
      (2)   The petitioners' committee withdraws the petition; or
      (3)   The Council repeals the ordinance; or   
      (4)   Election results have been certified showing that a majority of the
electors voting on the referred ordinance voted in favor thereof.
(Enacted 11-3-70)
SECTION 15.06   ACTION ON PETITIONS.
   (a)   Action by Council on Initiative and Referendum. When an initiative or
referendum petition has been finally determined sufficient, the Council shall
promptly consider the proposed initiative ordinance or reconsider the referred
ordinance by voting its repeal. If the Council fails to adopt a proposed
initiative measure without any change in substance within sixty (60) days or
fails to repeal the referred measure within thirty (30) days after the date the
petition was finally determined sufficient, it shall submit the proposed or
referred measure to the electors of the City.
   (b)   Recall Notification. At such time as a recall petition or supplemental
petition shall be certified by the Clerk of Council to be sufficient, he shall
at once submit the same with his certificate to the Council and shall notify by
registered mail the officer sought to be recalled by such action. If the
official whose removal is sought does not resign within five (5) days after
such notice, the Council at its next regular meeting following the expiration
of such five (5) day period, or at a special meeting called for such purpose,
shall order and fix a day for holding a recall election.
   (c)   Submission to Electors. The election on a proposed or referred
ordinance shall be fixed by Council and shall be held not less than sixty (60)
days and not later than six (6) months from the date of the final Council vote
on the measure fixing the date of the election.
Copies of the proposed or referred ordinance shall be made available at the
polls. A recall election shall be held not less than forty (40) days nor later
than fifty (50) days after the date on which Council fixes the date of the
recall election.
   Such election shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in
May or November of any year if such date falls within the period prescribed fur
such election. If such date does not fall within the prescribed period or if
Council in its discretion determines that such election should be held at an
earlier date within the prescribed period, Council shall provide for a special
election to be held on some other date. The election authorities shall publish
notice and make all arrangements for holding such elections, which shall be
conducted and the results thereof returned and declared in all respects as are
the results of regular municipal elections.
   A recall election shall be submitted to the voters of the entire City if
such officer to be recalled was elected by the voters of the entire City, and
such recall election shall be submitted to the voters of a single ward if the
officer to be recalled was elected by the voters of a single ward.
   (d)   Withdrawal of Petitions. An initiative or referendum or recall
petition may be withdrawn at any time prior to the fifteenth (15th) day
preceding the day of the election by filing with the Clerk of Council a request
for withdrawal signed by at least four (4) members of the petitioners'
committee. Upon the filing of such request the petition shall have no further
force or effect and all proceedings thereon shall be terminated.
(Enacted 11-3-70)
SECTION 15.07   BALLOT FORM.
   The ballots used when voting upon a proposed ordinance or an ordinance
subject to the referendum shall state the title of the ordinance to be voted on
and below it two propositions "For the Ordinance" and "Against the Ordinance".
Immediately to the left of each proposition there shall be a square in which by
making a cross (X) the voter may vote for or against the ordinance.
   The ballots used when voting upon a recall shall, with respect to each
person whose removal is sought, submit the question: "Shall (name of person) be
removed from the office of (name of office) by recall?" Immediately following
each such question, there shall be printed on the ballots the two propositions
in the order set forth: "For the recall of (name of person). " "Against the
recall of (name of person)." Immediately to the left of each proposition there
shall be a square in which by making a cross (X) the voter may vote for either
of such propositions. (Enacted 11-3-70)
SECTION 15.08   RESULTS OF ELECTION.
   (a)   Initiative. If a majority of the qualified electors voting on a
proposed initiative ordinance vote in its favor, it shall be considered adopted
upon certification of election results and shall be treated in all respects in
the same manner as ordinances of the same kind adopted by the Council, except
that no measure initiated by the people and adopted by popular vote shall be
subject to any veto of the Mayor, or shall be repealed by the Council, or so
amended by it as to destroy the effectiveness thereof, within two years after
it takes effect. If conflicting ordinances are approved at the same election,
the one receiving the greatest number of affirmative votes shall prevail to the
extent of such conflict.
   (b)   Referendum. If a majority of the qualified electors voting on a
referred ordinance vote against it, it shall be considered repealed upon
certification of the election results. If an identical or similar ordinance is
reconsidered by the Council within two (2) years from the effective date of the
referendum, it shall require for passage an affirmative vote of three-fourths
(3/4) of the members elected to Council.
   (c)   Recall. The incumbent, if not recalled in such election, shall
continue in office for the remainder of his unexpired term subject to the
recall as before except as provided in this Charter. If recalled in the recall
election, he shall regardless of any technical defects in the recall petition,
be deemed removed from office upon the announcement of the official results of
that election, and the office shall be filled as in the case of a vacancy for
any other reason. The successor of any person so removed shall hold office
during the unexpired term of his predecessor and shall himself be subject to
provision of the Charter.
(Enacted 11-3-70)
SECTION 15.09   DEFINITION OF "ORDINANCE".
   As used in this Article, the word "ordinance" includes a resolution.
(Enacted 11-3-70)
ARTICLE XVI
AMENDMENTS TO CHARTER
SECTION 16.01   METHODS AND PROCEDURE.
   Council may, by the affirmative vote of not less than two-thirds (2/3) of
its members, submit to the electors at the next regular November election any
proposed amendment or amendments to this Charter; or upon the filing of a
petition signed by electors numbering not less than ten percent (10%) of the
total vote cast in the Municipality at the last preceding November election,
setting forth any proposed amendment or amendments to this Charter, the Council
shall forthwith submit such proposed amendment or amendments to the electors in
accordance, in each instance, with the provisions of the Constitution and laws
of Ohio now or hereafter in effect.
   The petition aforesaid shall be filed with the Clerk of the Council who
shall present same to the Council at its next regular meeting.
SECTION 16.02   ADOPTION.
   If any such amendment is approved by a majority of the electors voting
thereon, it shall become a part of this Charter, except that if two or more
inconsistent proposed amendments on the same subject shall be submitted at the
same election, only the one of such amendments receiving the highest number of
affirmative votes, not less than a majority, shall become a part of this
Charter.
ARTICLE XVII
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION 17.01   EFFECTIVE DATE OF CHARTER.
   For the purpose of nominating and electing officers of the City and fixing
the compensation of those to be elected in 1961, this Charter shall be in
effect from and after the time of its approval by the electors of the City; and
for all other purposes it shall be in effect on and after the first day of
January, 1962.
SECTION 17.02   CONTINUANCE OF PRESENT OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.
   Unless otherwise provided in this Charter, all persons who are appointees,
employees or non-elected officials of the City at the time this Charter takes
effect, shall continue in office and in the performance of their duties until
provisions shall have been made otherwise in accordance with the provisions of
this Charter. When such provisions shall have been made, the term of any such
appointee, employee or non-elected official, affected thereby, shall expire.
   The powers which are conferred, and the duties which are imposed upon any
appointee, employee or non-elected official, commission, board, department or
division of the City under the laws of the State, shall, if such office,
department or division be abolished by this Charter, be thereafter exercised
and discharged by the officer, board, department or division upon whom are
imposed corresponding functions, powers and duties hereunder.
SECTION 17.03   OATH OF OFFICE.
   Every officer of the City shall, before entering upon the duties of his
office, take and subscribe to an oath, or affirmation that he will in all
respects faithfully discharge the duties of his office, that he will profess
loyalty to the Constitution of the United States of America, to the
Constitution of the State of Ohio, and that he will uphold this Charter and all
of the laws of this City. This oath or affirmation is to be filed and kept in
the office of the Clerk of Council.
SECTION 17.04   EFFECT OF CHARTER UPON EXISTING LAWS AND RIGHTS.
   The adoption of this Charter shall not affect any pre-existing rights of the
City, nor any right or liability or pending suit or prosecution, either on
behalf of or against the City, nor any franchise granted by the City, nor
pending proceedings for the authorization of public improvements or the levy of
assessments therefor. All ordinances and resolutions in force at the time of
the taking effect of this Charter, not inconsistent with its provisions shall
continue in force until amended or repealed.
SECTION 17.05   INTERPRETATION OF THE CHARTER.
   The Article and Section headings herein are inserted for convenient
reference only and are not intended to define, extend or limit the scope, or
otherwise affect any provision of this Charter. Wherever in this Charter the
male gender is used, it is hereby understood that it shall include the female
gender.
(Amended 11-5-85)
SECTION 17.06   SEPARABILITY.
   If any section or part of a section of this Charter shall be held to be
invalid or unconstitutional by a Court of competent jurisdiction, the same
shall not be held to invalidate or impair the validity, force or effect of any
other section or part of a section of this Charter, unless it clearly appears
that such other section or part of a section is wholly or necessarily dependent
for its operation upon the section or part of a section so held
unconstitutional or invalid.
SECTION 17.07   CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   It is hereby declared to be the policy of this City that municipal officials
and employees shall impartially and faithfully exercise their official
functions without the influence of private interest and that:
   (a)   All elected officers of the City, or employees of the City or members
of any Board or Commission of the City, whether directly or indirectly:
      (1)   Shall not be interested in any contract with the City;
      (2)   Shall not be interested in any contract, work or service, or in any
acquisition by the City of any property, other than by condemnation, the cost
of which is payable from City funds or in any purchase of any property from the
City;
      (3)   Shall not have any interest in, other than their fixed compensation
and reimbursable expenses, any expenditure of funds by the City;
      (4)   Shall not ask, demand, or receive any private compensation or
reward for the performance of their public duties.
   (b)   No person within a period of one year after termination of his
services as Mayor, member of Council, or as an officer or employee of the City
or as a member of any Board or Commission of the City shall accept private
employment or receive private compensation for services, whether as attorney,
agent, or employee, with respect to any matter which was under his charge
during the period of such service.
   (c)   Any officer or employee of the City, or member of any Board or
Commission of the City, who has a financial interest in any business, firm or
corporation affected by any legislation or other matter pending before any City
agency of which he is a member or employee, or who has any other private
interest in any such legislation or pending matter, shall not vote upon or take
any other official action with respect to the legislation or pending matter.
   (d)   All persons who are appointed to offices, boards or commissions shall,
within thirty (30) days after such appointment, and thereafter annually on or
before April 15 of every calendar year, file with the Ohio Ethics Commission
whatever financial disclosure statement that State law, in effect at such time,
requires such person to file.
   (e)   Any City officer or employee or member of any Board or Commission of
the City who willfully conceals such a financial interest or willfully violates
the requirements of this section shall be guilty of malfeasance in office or
position and shall forfeit his office or position. Violation of this section
with the knowledge expressed or implied of the person or corporation
contracting with or making a sale to the City, shall render the contract or
sale voidable by the Council.
   (f)   No person shall be deemed to be interested in any contract or
expenditure of funds by the City by reason of being a shareholder of a
corporation doing business with the City if he owns less than five (5) percent
of the stock of such corporation. (Enacted 11-3-70; Amended 11-4-75; 11-6-90)

CHAPTER 101
Codified Ordinances
101.01   Designation; how cited.
101.02   Interpretation.
101.03   Separability.
101.04   Headings.
101.99   General penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Waiver of legal publication on new matter in codification - see Ohio R.C.
731.23
      Certified copies of ordinances received in evidence - see Ohio R.C.
731.42
      Ordinances and resolutions - see ADM. Ch.
113
101.01 DESIGNATION; HOW CITED.
   The provisions contained in this Administrative Code and in the following
component Codes shall constitute The Codified Ordinances of Middleburg Heights,
Ohio, 1961, and may be so cited.
   The Codified Ordinances of Middleburg Heights, Ohio, or any of its component
Codes, may be referred to and cited as "the Municipal Code," "this Code" or
"component Code."
101.02 INTERPRETATION.
   In the construction of the Codified Ordinances the following rules shall
control, excepting those inconsistent with the manifest intent of Council as
disclosed in a particular provision, section or Code:
   (a)   Calendar - Computation of Time. “Month” and “year” shall mean the
calendar month or year. The time expressed in days within which an act is to be
done or a period is to expire shall he computed by excluding the first and
including the last day except if the last be Sunday it shall be excluded. If
time is expressed in hours the whole of Sunday shall be excluded.
   (b)   City and Municipality. "City" and "Municipality" shall mean the
Municipality of Middleburg Heights, Ohio.
   (c)   Conjunctions. "And" shall include "or" and "or" shall include "and",
if the sense so requires.
   (d)   Council. "Council" means the Council of Middleburg Heights, Ohio.
   (e)   Gender. Words importing the masculine shall extend and be applied to
the feminine and neuter genders.
   (f)   General Rule. Excepting as otherwise provided in this section, words
and phrases shall be construed according to the common usage of language;
provided, however, that technical words and phrases and such others as may have
acquired a special meaning in the law, shall be construed according to such
technical or special meaning.
   Whenever in the Codified Ordinances authority is given to an officer or an
act is required to be performed, such authority may be exercised and such act
may be performed at the instance of such officer, by a deputy or subordinate
unless contrary to law or to the clear intent of any such particular provision.
   (g)   Joint Authority. Words giving authority to a Board, Commission or to
three or more Municipal officers or employees or other persons shall be
construed as giving authority to a majority thereof unless otherwise
specifically provided.
   (h)   Number. Words in the plural shall include the singular and in the
singular shall include the plural number.
   (i)   Owner. "Owner" when applied to property, shall include any part owner,
joint owner or tenant in common, of the whole or any part of such property.
   (j)   Person. "Person" shall extend to and be applied to associations,
clubs, corporations, firms and partnerships, as well as to individuals.
   (k)   Premises. "Premises" when used as applicable to property shall extend
to and include land and buildings.
   (l)   Public Authority. "Public Authority" shall extend to and include the
Board of Education of the Municipality, the Municipality, the County
Commissioners, the State of Ohio, the United States of America, and any duly
authorized public official.
   (m)   Property. "Property" shall include real and personal, and any mixed
and lesser estates or interests therein; the words "personal property" shall
include every kind of property except real property; and the words "real
property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   (n)   Reasonable Time. In all cases where provision is made for an act to be
done or notice to be given within a reasonable time, it shall be deemed to mean
such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such act or
giving of such notice.
   (o)   Sidewalk. "Sidewalk" shall mean that portion of the street, located
between the curb line and the line of the next adjacent property intended for
use by pedestrians.
   (p)   Street. "Street" shall be construed to include alleys, avenues,
boulevards, lanes, roads, streets and other public ways in the Municipality.
   (q)   Tenant or Occupant. "Tenant" or "occupant" as applied to a building or
land shall extend and be applied to any person holding a written or oral lease
of or who occupies the whole or any part of a building or land, alone or with
others.
   (r)   Tenses. The use of any verb in the present tense shall include the
future.
101.03 SEPARABILITY.
   Each section and each part of each section of the Codified Ordinances is
hereby declared to be an independent section or part of a section and,
notwithstanding any other evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared
to be the controlling legislative intent that if any such section or part of a
section, or any provision thereof, or the application thereof to any person or
circumstances, is held to be invalid, the remaining sections or parts of
sections and the application of such provision to any other person or
circumstances, other than those as to which it is held invalid, shall not be
affected thereby, and it is hereby declared to be the legislative intent that
the Codified Ordinances would have been adopted independently of such section,
sections or parts of a section so held to be invalid.
101.04 HEADINGS.
   The headings of the several sections, chapters and titles of the Codified
Ordinances are intended as catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections,
chapters and titles and shall not be deemed to be a part of the sections of
law.
101.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Wherever in the Codified Ordinances, any act is prohibited or is made or
declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in the
Codified Ordinances the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any
act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided
therefore, the violation of any such provision of the Codified Ordinances is
hereby made a misdemeanor, and any violator, upon conviction by the court,
shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 1973-195. Passed 11-27-73.)

   The design of the official seal of the City, attached to original Resolution
1976-104, passed June 22, 1976, and incorporated herein by reference, is hereby
adopted as the seal of the City to be used wherever appropriate in Municipal
correspondence, identification or otherwise for official purposes only. The
official seal of the City shall not be used in any manner for private and
commercial purposes.
(Res. 1983-91. Passed 7-26-83.)
103.02 SEAL REQUIRED ON CITY VEHICLES; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service shall cause the official seal of the
City to be affixed to all motor vehicles owned by the City except those motor
vehicles listed in subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   Motor vehicles used by the Detective Bureau, the Juvenile Bureau and
the Chief of Police shall not bear the official seal.
(Ord. 1986-38. Passed 4-8-86.)

   The design of the official flag of the City, attached to Resolution 2006-48
and incorporated herein by reference, is hereby adopted as the flag of the City
to be used wherever appropriate for official municipal purposes only. The
official flag of the City shall not be used in any manner for private or
commercial purposes. (Res. 2006-48. Passed 6-27-06.)

105.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The City is hereby subdivided into four wards, which are equal in number of
the members of Council who are hereafter to be elected from wards according to
law, and such four wards are hereby created and established in this City, and
the boundaries thereof shall be such as are hereinafter set forth, which
boundaries are so fixed that each ward shall contain as nearly as practicable
an equal number of inhabitants. The boundaries of the wards shall be as
follows. (Ord. 1965-121. Passed 12-28-65.)

follows:

Middlebrook Boulevard;

Bagley Road;

(Ord. 1998-81. Passed 10-13-98.)

   Thence westerly along the centerline of Sprague Road and the southerly

   Thence northwesterly along the centerline of Normandie Boulevard to the

   Thence westerly and northerly along the centerline of Lucerne Drive to the

   Thence southeasterly along the centerline of Pearl Road to the centerline of
Interstate 71;
   Thence northerly along the centerline of Interstate 71 to the centerline of
Fowles Road;
   Thence westerly along the centerline of Fowles Road to the centerline of Big
Creek Parkway also known as Brookside Parkway;
   Thence northerly along the centerline of Big Creek Parkway to the centerline
of Interstate 71;
   Thence northerly along the centerline of Interstate 71 to the centerline of
Bagley Road;
   Thence easterly along the centerline of Bagley Road to the centerline of
Craigmere Drive and the place of beginning.
(Ord. 1998-81. Passed 10-13-98.)
105.04 THIRD WARD.
   The Third Ward shall contain all that territory bounded and described as
follows:
   Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of Bagley Road and
Middlebrook Boulevard;
   Thence northerly along the centerline of Middlebrook Boulevard to the
centerline of Ramona Drive;
   Thence easterly along the centerline of Ramona Drive to the centerline of
Elise Drive;
   Thence northeasterly along the centerline of Elise Drive and the easterly
line of Sublot No. 97 in the Brookridge Subdivision No. 2 to the northeasterly
line of Sublot No. 97;
   Thence northwesterly along the northeasterly line of Sublot No. 97 to the
northwesterly line of Sublot No. 75;
   Thence northeasterly along the northwesterly line of Sublot No. 75 to the
centerline of Maureen Drive;
   Thence westerly along the centerline of Maureen Drive to the centerline of
Middlebrook Boulevard;
   Thence northerly along the centerline of Middlebrook Boulevard to the
centerline of Smith Road;
   Thence westerly and northerly along the centerline of Smith Road to the
northerly corporation line of the City;
   Thence easterly along the northern corporation line to the centerline of
West 130th Street, being also the easterly corporation line of the City;
   Thence southerly along the centerline of West 130th Street to the centerline
of Bagley Road;
   Thence westerly and northwesterly along the centerline of Bagley Road to the
centerline of Hyde Park Drive;
   Thence northeasterly along the centerline of Hyde Park Drive to the
centerline of Seneca Trail;
   Thence northwesterly along the centerline of Seneca Trail to the centerline
of Pearl Road;
   Thence southwesterly along the centerline of Pearl Road to the center line
of Bagley Road;
   Thence northwesterly along the centerline of Bagley Road to the centerline
of Middlebrook Boulevard, being the place of beginning.
(Ord. 1998-81. Passed 10-13-98.)
105.05 FOURTH WARD.
   The Fourth Ward shall contain all that territory bounded and described as
follows:
   Beginning in the centerline of Webster Road at its intersection with the
southerly corporation line of the City;
   Thence northerly and northwesterly along the centerline of Webster Road to
the centerline of the Baldwin Creek;
   Thence northeasterly along the centerline of the Baldwin Creek to the
centerline of Bagley Road;
   Thence southeasterly along the centerline of Bagley Road to the easterly
corporation line of the City;
   Thence southerly along the easterly corporation line of the City to the
southerly corporation line of the City;
   Thence westerly along the southerly corporation line to the centerline of
Webster Road, being the place of beginning.
(Ord. 1982-143. Passed 10-26-82.)
CHAPTER 107
Public Meetings
107.01   Interpretation; purpose.
107.02   Definitions.
107.03   Public meetings required; minutes.
107.04   Notice.
107.05   Executive sessions.
107.06   Noncompliance; effect of action taken; equitable relief.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Council meetings - see CHTR.
4.06; ADM.
111.01 
      Boards and commissions - see CHTR.
Art. X 
      Open public meetings required - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
      Notice of Council meetings - see ADM.
111.06
107.01 INTERPRETATION; PURPOSE.
   This chapter shall be liberally construed to require appointed or elected
public officials of the City to take official action and to conduct all
deliberations upon official business only in open meetings, unless the subject
matter is specifically excepted by law.
(Ord. 1975-198. Passed 10-28-75.)
107.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business of a
public body by a majority of its members.
      (Ord. 1975-198. Passed 10-28-75.)
   (b)   "Public body" means either of the following:
      (1)   Any board, commission, committee or similar decision-making body of
a State agency, institution or authority, and any legislative authority or
board, commission, committee, agency, authority or similar decision- making
body of any county, township, municipal corporation, school district or other
political subdivision or local public institution; or
      (2)   Any committee or subcommittee of a body described in paragraph (b)
(1) hereof.
   (c)   "Regulated individual" means:
      (1)   Any student in a State or local public educational institution; and
      (2)   Any person who is, voluntarily or involuntarily, an inmate, patient
or resident of a State or local institution because of criminal behavior,
mental illness or retardation, disease, disability, age or other condition
requiring custodial care.
(Ord. 1994-13. Passed 3-22-94.)
107.03 PUBLIC MEETINGS REQUIRED; MINUTES.
   All meetings of any public body are declared to be public meetings open to
the public at all times. A member of a public body must be present in person at
a meeting open to the public to be considered present or to vote at the meeting
and for purposes of determining whether a quorum is present at the meeting.
   In times of emergency, declared by the President of the United States, the
Governor of the State of Ohio, or the Cuyahoga County Executive, a public body
may meet by teleconference, video conference, or other electronic means,
provided the meeting is open to the public. A member or members of the public
body may attend such meeting by teleconference, video conference, or other
electronic means. Each member of the public body attending in such a manner
shall be deemed present in person to vote at the meeting and present in person
for purposes of determining whether a quorum is present at the meeting.
   The minutes of a regular or special meeting of any such public body shall be
promptly prepared, filed and maintained, and shall be open to public
inspection. The minutes need only reflect the general subject matter of
discussions in executive sessions authorized under Section
107.05. (Ord. 1994-13. Passed 3-22-94; Ord. 2020-91. Passed 11-24-20.)
107.04 NOTICE.
   Every public body shall, by rule, establish a reasonable method whereby any
person may determine the time and place of all regularly scheduled meetings and
the time, place and purpose of all special meetings. A public body shall not
hold a special meeting unless it gives at least twelve hours advance notice to
the news media that have requested notification, except in the event of an
emergency requiring immediate official action. In the event of an emergency,
the member or members calling the meeting shall notify the news media that have
requested notification immediately of the time, place and purpose of the
meeting.
   The rule shall provide that any person may, upon request and payment of a
reasonable fee, obtain reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which
any specific type of public business is to be discussed. Provisions for advance
notification may include, but are not limited to, mailing the agenda of
meetings to all subscribers on a mailing list or mailing notices in self-
addressed, stamped envelopes provided by the person.
(Ord. 1975-198. Passed 10-28-75.)
107.05 EXECUTIVE SESSIONS.
   The members of a public body may hold an executive session only after a
majority of a quorum of the public body determines, by a roll call vote, to
hold such a session, and only at a regular or special meeting for the sole
purpose of the consideration of any of the following matters:
   (a)   To consider the appointment, employment, dismissal, discipline,
promotion, demotion or compensation of a public employee or official, or the
investigation of charges or complaints against a public employee, official,
licensee or regulated individual, unless the public employee, official,
licensee or regulated individual requests a public hearing. Except as otherwise
provided by law, no public body shall hold an executive session for the
discipline of an elected official for conduct relating to the performance of
his or her official duties or for his or her removal from office. If a public
body holds an executive session pursuant to this subsection, the motion and
vote to hold that executive session shall state which one or more of the
approved purposes listed in this subsection are the purposes for which the
executive session is to be held, but need not include the name of any person to
be considered at the meeting.
If a public body holds an executive session to consider any of the matters
listed in subsections (b) to (f) hereof, the motion and vote to hold that
executive session shall state which one or more of the approved matters listed
in such subsections are to be considered at the executive session.
   (b)   To consider the purchase of property for public purposes, or the sale
of property at competitive bidding, if premature disclosure of information
would give an unfair competitive or bargaining advantage to a person whose
personal, private interest is adverse to the general public interest. No member
shall use this subsection as a subterfuge for providing covert information to
prospective buyers or sellers. A purchase or sale of public property is void if
the seller or buyer of the public property has received covert information from
a member that has not been disclosed to the general public in sufficient time
for other prospective buyers and sellers to prepare and submit offers.
If the minutes of the public body show that all meetings and deliberations of
the public body have been conducted in compliance with this section, any
instrument executed by the public body purporting to convey, lease or otherwise
dispose of any right, title or interest in any public property shall be
conclusively presumed to have been executed in compliance with this section
insofar as title or other interest of any bona fide purchaser, lessee or
transferee of the property is concerned.
   (c)   Conferences with an attorney for the public body, concerning disputes
involving the public body that are the subject of pending or imminent court
action;
   (d)   Preparing for, conducting or reviewing negotiations or bargaining
sessions with public employees concerning their compensation or other terms and
conditions of their employment;
   (e)   Matters required to be kept confidential by Federal law or rules or
State statutes; or
   (f)   Specialized details of security arrangements where disclosure of the
matters discussed might reveal information that could be used for the purpose
of committing, or avoiding prosecution for, a violation of the law.
(Ord. 1975-198. Passed 10-28-75; Ord. 1994-13. Passed 3-22-94.)
   (g)   To consider confidential information related to the marketing plans,
specific business strategy, production techniques, trade secrets, or personal
financial statements of an applicant for economic development assistance, or to
negotiations with other political subdivisions respecting requests for economic
development assistance, provided that both of the following conditions apply:
      (1)   The information is directly related to a request for economic
development assistance that is to be provided or administered under any
provision of Chapter 715., 725., 1724., or 1728. or sections 701.07, 3735.67 to
3735.70, 5709.40 to 5709.43, 5709.61 to 5709.69, 5709.73 to 5709.75, or 5709.77
to 5709.81 of the Revised Code, or that involves public infrastructure
improvements or the extension of utility services that are directly related to
an economic development project.
      (2)   A unanimous quorum of the public body determines, by a roll call
vote, that the executive session is necessary to protect the interests of the
applicant or the possible investment or expenditure of public funds to be made
in connection with the economic development project.
107.06 NONCOMPLIANCE; EFFECT OF ACTION TAKEN; EQUITABLE RELIEF.
   A resolution, rule or formal action of any kind is invalid unless adopted in
an open meeting of the public body. A resolution, rule or formal action adopted
in an open meeting that results from deliberations in a meeting not open to the
public is invalid unless the deliberations were for a purpose specifically
authorized in Section
107.05 and conducted at an executive session held in compliance with such
section. A resolution, rule or formal action adopted in an open meeting is
invalid if the public body that adopted the resolution, rule or formal action
violated Section
107.04.
(Ord. 1994-13. Passed 3-22-94.)

139.03(g)
111.01 RULES OF COUNCIL.
I.   MEETINGS
   Effective January 1, 2025, the regular meetings of Council shall be held in
the Municipal Building at 6:00 p.m. on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each
and every calendar month. Special meetings of Council may be called by the
Mayor or by any three members of Council by having the Clerk of Council serve
written notice of the call of such meeting upon each member of Council and upon
the Mayor in person or by delivering a copy thereof to the usual place of
residence of such persons not less than twelve hours prior to the holding of
such meeting. Such notice shall specify the time and place for the holding of
such meeting.
(Ord. 1992-82. Passed 9-8-82; Ord. 1999-54. Passed 6-8-99; Ord. 2017-38. Passed
6-13-17; Ord. 2024-99. Passed 12-10-24.)
II.   HOLIDAY MEETINGS.
   When any regular meeting of Council falls due on a legal holiday, or on an
election day, Council shall meet in regular session on the day following, and
at the place and hour fixed by the Rule governing the same.
(Ord. 1982-136. Passed 10-26-82.)
III.   AGENDA.
   The Clerk of Council, with the advice of the President of Council, shall
cause an agenda to be prepared for the meetings of Council. Such agenda shall
include all matters to be acted upon at the next Council meeting. Such agenda
shall be mailed or otherwise delivered to each member of Council, the Mayor,
the Engineer, the Director of Finance and the Law Director at least twenty-four
hours prior to the scheduled time of the meeting. Any matter not appearing on
the agenda shall not be subject to formal action by Council. This rule may be
suspended as provided in Rule XXII.
   A sponsor of legislation may, at any time prior to its introduction, ask the
Clerk to remove any matter from the agenda. If two regular meetings of Council
have passed without a piece of legislation on the agenda having been
introduced, the Clerk shall automatically remove it from the agenda.
(Ord. 1983-17. Passed 2-8-83.)
IV.   ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   The business of the regular meetings of Council shall be transacted in the
following order:
   1.   Roll call;
   2.   Reading and disposal of the journal;
   3.   Communications, petitions and claims outside of officials and offices
of the City Hall;
   4.   Audience participation;
   5.   Appointments and confirmations;
   6.   Ordinances and resolutions;
   7.   Reports of Council committees;
   8.   Reports and communications from the Mayor, directors of departments and
other City officials; and
   The presiding officer of Council may, at any time, permit a member to
introduce an ordinance, motion or resolution out of the regular order for the
same, unless the same is objected to by a majority of the members present.
V.   OPENING PROCEEDINGS.
   The President of Council shall take the chair at the time appointed for
Council to meet and shall immediately call the members to order. The President
shall then cause the journal of the preceding session to be read and disposed
of, unless otherwise ordered by Council. In the absence of the President of
Council, the President pro tem of Council shall perform such duties as are
imposed upon the President. In the absence of both the President and the
President pro tem, Council may appoint a temporary Chairperson or President.
VI.   DEBATES AND DISCUSSIONS.
   The President of Council shall preserve order and decorum and shall confine
members in debate to the question. Discussion and questions pertaining to a
resolution or ordinance may properly be heard at the time of the first, second
or third reading. The President may, in common with any other member, call any
member to order who violates any of the Rules, and shall, when in the chair,
decide all questions of order, subject to any appeal to Council on the demand
of two members. On such appeal there shall be no debate, but the member making
the appeal may briefly state the reasons for the same, and the presiding
officer shall have the same right to a similar statement.
   No member of Council, while Council is in session, shall engage in debate or
discussion with anyone save another member of Council, the President or some
person who has either been granted by Council the privilege to address Council
or is present at a Council meeting on the invitation of Council.
   Any member of Council may, however, request that any person attending a
meeting be permitted to address Council at any time, in addition to the time
specifically designated for audience participation. The President shall permit
such person to address Council, upon the consent of the majority of members of
Council, at any reasonable and appropriate occasion during the meeting. The
President may provide a time limit for such person's address to Council. All
such debates and discussions shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order.
VII.   HEARINGS.
   If any elector or taxpayer of the Municipality or any other person desires a
hearing on any matter pending before Council, application may be made therefor
to Council and Council may, by a two-thirds vote, grant such public hearing by
arranging for a special time and place therefor, which must not be during any
regular or special meeting of Council.
(Ord. 1982-137. Passed 10-25-82.)
VIII.   VOTING.
   (a)   Every member present shall vote on every question (except the approval
of minutes) on the call of the yeas and nays, unless excused by the unanimous
consent of Council. Any member wishing to be excused from voting must state the
reason for the abstention on the record during discussion before a roll call
vote has begun. If there is no objection the member will be excused from
voting.
   (b)   Any member who abstains without being unanimously excused may be
censured for contempt by a majority vote of Council.
   (c)   On each successive roll call vote the order of voting will be rotated
so that the first to vote on the previous roll call will be the last to vote on
the following roll call. The order of voting will otherwise repeat the order of
the previous roll call vote.
(Ord. 2014-8. Passed 2-25-14.)
IX.   INTRODUCING ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS.
   Ordinances and resolutions shall be introduced only by members of Council
present, with their names endorsed thereon, with the following exceptions:
   1.   An ordinance or resolution introduced by the chair of a committee
shall, with the consent of the members of such committee, include the names of
the individual committee members as co-sponsors.
   2.   An ordinance or resolution introduced by a member of Council or the
Mayor and thereafter referred to a committee which the sponsor does not chair
may, with the consent of the sponsor, include the names of the committee
members as co-sponsors.
   3.   A resolution memorializing an individual or group of individuals may,
with the consent of such individual or group of individuals, be introduced by
the entire Council.
   4.   An ordinance required by law may be introduced by any member of Council
present and shall state: "Introduced by Requirement of Law. "
X.   MOTIONS; WHEN DEBATABLE; WITHDRAWAL.
   When a motion is made and seconded, it shall be stated by the presiding
officer before any debate shall be in order. Any such motion, and any amendment
thereto, may be withdrawn by the movers thereof at any time before decision, if
a majority of the members then present agree thereto.
XI.   DIVISION OF QUESTIONS.
   Any member may call for a division of the question, or the presiding officer
may direct the same, and in either case the same shall be divided if it
comprehends questions so distinct that one being taken away, the other will
stand as an entire question for decision.
XII.   ADJOURNMENT.
   The motion to adjourn shall always be in order, unless Council is engaged in
voting, and the motion to adjourn or to lay on the table or for the previous
question shall be decided without debate.
XIII.   SUBSIDIARY MOTIONS; ORDER OF PRECEDENCE.
   When a question or proposition is before Council, or under debate, no motion
shall be received except the following:
   1.   To adjourn;
   2.   To lay on the table;
   3.   For the previous question;
   4.   To postpone to a certain day;
   5.   To commit;
   6.   To amend; or
   7.   To postpone indefinitely.
   The several motions shall have precedence in the order in which they are
herein arranged.
XIV.   RULES OF ORDER.
   In the absence of any rule upon the matter of business, Council shall be
governed by Robert's Rules of Order.
XV.   STANDING COMMITTEES.
   At no later than the first regular meeting of Council after its
organization, the President of Council shall appoint standing committees, each
consisting of three members (the first named to be Chairperson) of the
following subjects:
   1.   City Parks, Recreation and Services. This Committee shall have
legislative and review responsibility for matters pertaining to recreation
programs and the use of public parks, playgrounds and other public property for
public purposes. It shall also have responsibility for equipment and materials
for the maintenance of public properties.
   2.   Finance, Taxation and Assessments. This Committee shall have
legislative and review responsibility for matters pertaining to City finance,
indebtedness, appropriations, taxation and the Department of Finance, including
the payment of moneys not previously provided for and the establishment of
salaries, wages, pensions and utility rates.
   3.   Legislation and Rules. This Committee shall have legislative and review
responsibility for matters pertaining to County, State and Federal legislation
affecting the City, such as annexations and redistricting, initiative,
referendum and recall petitions, printing and advertising, and also matters
pertaining to courts, licensing, fines, penalties, forfeitures and sentences.
Before final passage, any ordinance of a general or permanent nature may be
referred to this Committee for comparison with similar existing ordinances and
for reconciliation or report of any discrepancies.
   4.   Public Health, Safety and Relief. This Committee shall have legislative
and review responsibility for matters pertaining to the Police and Fire
Divisions, the Fire Prevention Code, fire inspection, public health concerns
(including waste collection and disposal), environmental pollution, health and
hospital services, and care of indigents.
   5.   Public Improvements. This Committee shall have legislative and review
responsibility for matters pertaining to the development or improvement of City
land or buildings, the sale and purchase of real estate, and other major
capital improvements, excluding those subjects specifically within the
jurisdiction of the Streets, Utilities and Railroad Committee.
   6.   Streets, Utilities and Railroad. This Committee shall have legislative
and review responsibility for matters pertaining to the development,
improvement or maintenance of streets, roadways, sewer lines, sidewalks, public
utility lines, grade crossings and other railroad concerns. It shall also have
responsibility for legislative matters pertaining to the sewage treatment
plant.
   7.   Zoning and Building Code. This Committee shall have legislative and
review responsibility for matters pertaining to City Planning, Zoning and
Building Codes and for Councilmatic relations with the boards working in those
areas, namely the Board of Zoning and Building Appeals and the Planning
Commission.
   The President of Council may, at any time, remove any appointed member of
any committee and appoint a new member to such committee to serve in place of
such member so removed. (Ord. 2002-33. Passed 5-28-02.)
XVI.   REFERENCE TO COMMITTEES.
   Any report, resolution, ordinance or matter before Council for consideration
(except appropriation ordinances) may, before its final passage, be referred
either to the standing committee to which the subject matter is most closely
related or to a committee specially appointed by the President of Council. Any
such committee shall consider the matter thus referred to it and report thereon
to Council without unnecessary delay. Any matter referred to a committee may be
taken from the hands of such committee for consideration by a two-thirds vote
of Council at any time prior to the report of such committee.
   The President of Council may make such referrals to any standing committee
designated in Rule XV, subject to an appeal by a majority of the members of
Council.
   Any standing committee may consider any subject matter designated in Rule XV
as within its jurisdiction without reference by Council or the President.
XVII. COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE.
   Council may meet publicly as a Committee of the Whole, if the President of
Council and/or Clerk of Council determines that there is an agenda for the
Committee and so notifies members of Council.
   The Committee of the Whole shall consider matters referred to it by any
member of Council or the Mayor. The Committee of the Whole may also hear
presentations and recommendations from any committee on matters to be submitted
to Council for a vote.
(Ord. 2002-13. Passed 5-28-02; Ord. 2025-7. Passed 2-11-25.)
XVIII. PRECEDENCE FOR REFERRAL.
   When there is a question of referring a given subject to a standing
committee or to a special committee, the question of reference to a standing
committee shall be put first.
XIX.   COMMITTEE REPORTS.
   Any committee shall consider matters referred to it and report thereon
without unnecessary delay. The report of any committee or Municipal officer on
matters referred by Council shall be made in writing and shall be accompanied
by the original papers on which the report is based, unless otherwise ordered
by Council.
   If any matter referred by Council to a committee or officer is not reported
on or within four weeks from the time of such reference or by any other
deadline imposed by Council, the Clerk of Council shall bring such matter to
the attention of Council, which shall take any action it may deem appropriate,
including the removal from the hands of a committee or officer any referred
matter, by a majority vote of Council.
(Ord. 1986-75. Passed 6-10-86.)
XX. COMMITTEE MEETINGS.
   Committee meetings shall be held at the call of the chair, or by two members
of the committee. The Clerk of Council shall post the scheduling of any
committee meetings. Committee meetings shall be open to the public at all
times, unless subject matter that would qualify for executive session before
the entire Council is to be discussed.
(Ord. 1990-147. Passed 10-9-90; Ord. 2025-7. Passed 2-11-25.)
XXI.   AMENDMENTS.
   These Rules may be amended or altered, or new Rules may be adopted, by a
vote of a majority of all the members elected at any meeting of Council, on the
report of the Legislation and Rules Committee, to which the subject has been
referred at a previous meeting.
(Ord. 1982-136. Passed 10-26-82.)
XXII. SUSPENSION OF RULES.
   These Rules, or any of them, may be temporarily suspended at any meeting of
Council, by a concurrent vote of a two-thirds majority of all members elected,
except when a greater number is required by law or by these Rules. The vote on
such suspension shall be taken by the yeas and nays and entered on the journal.
If any Rule has been inadvertently violated by Council, the same shall be
regarded as having been suspended.
(Ord. 1983-17. Passed 2-8-83.)
XXIII. RESIGNATION.
   The resignation of a member of Council shall not take effect until the same
has been accepted by a vote of a majority of the members, exclusive of the
person tendering the resignation. (Ord. 1982-136. Passed 10-26-82.)
111.02 CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   (a)    The Clerk of Council shall have the custody of the records of the
City, shall keep an accurate and complete journal of all the proceedings of
Council and shall perform such other duties as Council may require from time to
time.
(Ord. 1964-14. Passed 1-2-64.)
   (b)    The duties and responsibilities of the office of Clerk of Council are
as hereinafter enumerated, except that Council reserves the right to add
additional duties and responsibilities from time to time as it deems necessary.
      (1)    Meetings. Attend caucus, special and regular meetings of Council;
      (2)    Agenda. Prepare meeting agendas with the Administrative Assistant
to the Clerk of Council;
      (3)    Minutes. Prepare minutes of all meetings when in attendance;
      (4)    Legislation. Make copies of and distribute legislation;
         Review legislation prior to distribution;
         Assign numbers to legislation at special or regular meetings;
         Have legislation properly executed by the Mayor, the President of
Council and the Clerk of Council after the same has been passed;
         Certify, as true, copies of legislation and the date of posting of the
same on the bulletin board, for required distribution, and post such
legislation, for a permanent record, in books filed in his or her office;
      (5)    Public hearings. Prepare legal notices, advertise for public
hearings and mail out such notices to all persons, as required;
      (6)    Bids. Prepare legal notices, advertise for bidding and mail out
such notices to all companies as an invitation for them to bid;
         Receive such bids and be present at the opening of such bids;
         Prepare a tally on such bids;
         Prepare follow up letters for non-bidders;
      (7)    Communications. Prepare and mail out all necessary official
communications as instructed;
         Prepare official letters and memoranda for Councilmen;
         Investigate items requested by Council;
      (8)    Easements. Insure that easement files are properly maintained;
      (9)    Deeds. Insure that deed files are properly maintained;
      (10)    Research. Research minutes, files and old legislation for Council
members, as necessary to the performance of their offices;
      (11)    Liquor permits. Report applications from the Ohio Department of
Liquor Control to Council for permits in the City; have the applicant
investigated by the Police Division; submit an inquiry to the secretary of
State as to the names of officers of the corporation; submit an inquiry to the
State Tax Department as to the name of the statutory agent and follow up action
of Council to the Department of Liquor Control;
      (12)    Court. Appear in court with papers when subpoenaed;
      (13)    Election Board. Appear at the Election Board when necessary to
certify petitions, etc.;
      (14)    Transcripts. Assist the Law Director in preparing transcripts;
      (15)    Provide for purchase. Provide copies of the Codified Ordinances
of the City, the Zoning Code and the Zoning Map for purchase;
         Sell copies of legislation and Zoning Codes and reproduce individual
copies of legislation on the copy machine;
      (16)    Distribution of materials. Distribute copies of the Codified
Ordinances, supplemental Zoning Codes and updated sections of the Codified
Ordinances to the Mayor, Council, department heads, the Police Division and
members of boards and commissions;
      (17)    Improvement notifications. Notify residents relative to estimated
and final assessments in connection with improvements; and
      (18)    Custodian of records. Be the sole custodian of all records in his
or her office. (Ord. 1982-137. Passed 10-26-82.)
(Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
111.03 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT TO THE CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   There is hereby established a full-time position of Administrative Assistant
to the Clerk of Council. Appointment to or removal from such position shall be
by motion of Council, requiring the affirmative vote of a majority of Council.
The Administrative Assistant shall perform such duties as the Clerk or Council
may require or designate from time to time. During the absence or disability of
the Clerk, the Administrative Assistant shall perform the duties of the Clerk.
All duties shall be performed under the supervision of the Clerk.
(Ord. 1987-80. Passed 9-8-87; Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
111.04 CLERK-TYPIST. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section
111.04 was repealed by Ordinance 1982-139, passed October 26, 1982.)      
111.05 SMOKING PROHIBITED.
   No smoking shall be allowed in the Council Chambers during any regular or
special meeting of Council or during any formal public hearing of Council.
(Ord. 1971-8. Passed 2-23-71.)
111.06 NOTICE OF COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council shall annually, on or about January 2 of each
year, conspicuously post at the City Hall a notice of the date, time and place
of the regularly scheduled meetings of Council and shall, as soon as practical
after the call of a special meeting of Council, similarly post a notice of such
meeting including the purpose thereof. As used in this section, the term
“regularly scheduled meeting” includes all regularly scheduled caucuses of
Council.
   (b)   Upon request, the Clerk of Council shall provide, without cost and
once only to each such person requesting, a schedule of the date, time and
place of the regularly scheduled meetings of Council.
   (c)   In the event that any person requests notification of regular meetings
or special meetings or requests notification of meetings at which a specific
subject is to be officially discussed, such person shall submit in writing to
the Clerk of Council a request for notification specifying the type of
notification requested, which notification shall be for either:   
      (1)   All meetings;
      (2)   All special meetings;
      (3)   All special meetings called at other than regular meetings; or
      (4)   All meetings at which a specific subject is to be officially
discussed.
         (Res. 1975-245. Passed 12-23-75.)
111.07 ADVERTISING FOR BIDS.
   Whenever a contract is required to be let after public bidding pursuant to
the provisions of Section
9.05 of the City Charter, the Clerk of Council, upon being so authorized and
directed by Council, shall cause an advertisement to be published in a
newspaper of general circulation within the City once a week for two
consecutive weeks requesting the submission of bids. Such bids shall be opened
in the presence of the Clerk of Council or his or her designate, and either the
Mayor, the Director of Finance or the Assistant Director of Finance. The Clerk
of Council shall tabulate the bids and submit them to Council and Council shall
thereafter determine the lowest and best bidder.
(Ord. 1976-53. Passed 4-27-76; Ord. 1996-54. Passed 6-25-96.)
111.08 MEETINGS OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE OF COUNCIL. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 111.08 was repealed by Ordinance 1982-136, passed
October 26, 1982. See Section
111.01, Rule XVII.)

113.03 DUTY OF CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   The Clerk of Council is hereby ordered and directed to publish any and all

required by law to be published by posting the same as provided in the City
Charter, without any express or special order or direction as to any such
posting, save and except where publication other than by posting is specially
or expressly ordered or directed by Council or by law required.
(Ord. 8. Passed 3-19-28.)
113.04 NOTICE OF RESOLUTION OF NECESSITY.
   Whenever a resolution of necessity is passed by Council deeming it necessary
to make a public improvement to be paid for in whole or in part by special
assessment, levied under Ohio R.C. 727.01 through 727.49, and notice of such
passage is given by the City pursuant to Ohio R.C. 727.13, there shall be
included with the notice of passage that the Clerk of Council or his designee
is compelled to serve by such Section 727.13 upon each owner of a lot or parcel
of land to be assessed:
   (a)   A certified copy of the resolution of necessity; and
   (b)   The individual amounts of the estimated assessments pertaining to each
lot or parcel of land to be assessed in the improvement.
(Ord. 1974-103. Passed 9-24-74.)

1-10-23; Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
   (b)   If, on the effective date of this section (Ordinance 1984-162, passed
December 11, 1984), there are a greater number of full-time employees employed
in any classification than is authorized by division (b) of this section, then
such persons presently employed shall not be affected by such limitation. If
and when the number of such persons employed within a classification is reduced
to the maximum number of employees authorized by division (b) of this section,
then such employee limit shall not be exceeded unless authorized by the
Administration and Council.
(Ord. 1984-162. Passed 12-11-84.)

123.22 FULL-TIME HOUSING MANAGER.
   (a)   There is hereby established the full-time position of Housing Manager.
   (b)   Qualifications: The Housing Manager shall have a combination of
education and experience equivalent to graduation from a community college or
technical school with major course work in engineering or architecture. A four-
year degree is highly desirable. Considerable experience in housing code
enforcement and inspections work including supervisory experience is required.
A valid Ohio Driver’s License with an acceptable driving record is required.
Applicant must be physically able to access all areas of a property and its
structures.
   (c)   General Duties: Develops and implements housing and property
maintenance programs; responds to and investigates property maintenance
complaints and interprets and applies laws, regulations and policies.
   (d)   Appointing Authority: Building Commissioner.
   (e)   Salary Grade: 30.
(Ord. 2014-18. Passed 4-8-14; Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
123.23 FULL-TIME HOUSING INSPECTOR.
   (a)   There is hereby established two full-time positions of Housing
Inspector.
   (b)   Qualifications: The Housing Inspector shall have any combination of
education and experience equivalent to an Associates degree and experience in
building construction, real estate appraisal, building and/or housing related
field. A current certification as an ICC property maintenance and housing
inspector is highly desirable. A valid Ohio Driver’s License with an acceptable
driving record is required. Applicant must be able to access all areas of a
property and its structures.
   (c)   General Duties: Conduct property maintenance inspections; enforce
housing and related codes and ordinances; perform field inspections and re-
inspections of residential properties and facilities for compliance with
housing code standards; prepare notices of code violations for property owners
not in compliance; propose repair options to remedy violations.
   (d)   Appointing Authority: Building Commissioner.
   (e)   Salary Grade: 25.
(Ord. 2014-17. Passed 4-8-14; Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
123.231 FULL-TIME HOUSING INSPECTOR. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 123.231 was repealed by Ordinance No. 2024-41,
passed May 14, 2024.)

time. See Section
123.231.)

127.01 ESTABLISHMENT; DETECTIVE; TRAFFIC BUREAU.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Division of Police within the Department
of Public Safety, which Division shall be composed of one Chief of Police, one
full-time Deputy Chief/Lieutenant, four full-time Lieutenants, five full-time
Sergeants and up to twenty-three full- time Patrolmen. (Ord. 2003-65. Passed 9-
9-03.)
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall designate not more than three members of the
Division, other than the Chief of Police, as Detectives. (Ord. 1986-48. Passed
4-22-86.)
   (c)   The Chief of Police shall designate not more than three members of the
Division, other than the Chief of Police, as members of the Traffic Bureau, the
senior of whom shall be in charge of the Bureau. (Ord. 1981-88. Passed 6-9-81.)
(Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
127.02 CHIEF OF POLICE; APPOINTMENT, TERM, REMOVAL. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 127.02 was repealed by implication by the
adoption of the voters, on November 3, 1970, of new Sections
4.04,
7.04 and
7.06 of the City Charter.)
127.03 CIVIL SERVICE EXAMINATIONS.
   The positions of Sergeant provided for herein shall be filled after a
competitive examination from those persons presently full-time members of the
Division of Police in accordance with the civil service laws of the City or, in
the absence thereof, in accordance with the civil service laws of the State.
Regular members of the Division of Police shall be appointed by the Safety
Director in accordance with the civil service laws of the City or, in the
absence thereof, in accordance with the civil service laws of the State. All
existing full-time police officers presently serving shall be considered as
members of the Division of Police without re-appointment. (Ord. 1962-56. Passed
5-22-62.)
127.04 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION.
   Accompanying any application for employment as a police officer on a full-
time or part-time basis shall be a physical examination report of the
applicant, made by a physician licensed by the State. (Ord. 1963-77. Passed 5-
28-63.)
127.05 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Chief and other members of the Division of Police shall have the powers
and duties prescribed by the statutes of the State and such other powers and
duties as shall be prescribed by ordinance from time to time.
(Ord. 1962-56. Passed 5-22-62.)
127.06 BOND.
   All members of the Division of Police, whether regular or part-time, shall
furnish bond in such form and wording as shall be approved by the Law Director
in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000) for the faithful performance of his
duties, and otherwise conditioned as provided by law and with such surety as
shall be approved by the Mayor.
(Ord. 1962-56. Passed 5-22-62.)
127.07 POLICE RELIEF AND PENSION FUND. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: The provisions of Section
127.07 have been repealed by implication by the enactment of House Bill 642,
which established Ohio Revised Code Chapter 742, and which created a Statewide
disability and pension fund for policemen and firemen, abolishing all municipal
police and fire relief and pension funds as of January 1, 1967.)
127.08 AUXILIARY POLICE.
   The organization known as the Auxiliary Police is hereby recognized by the
Municipality.
   The organization will function under the direction of the Mayor, the Chief
of Police and the Director of Civil Defense in the event of emergencies or
disasters.
(Ord. 1958-52. Passed 8-11-58.)
127.09 UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.   
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Uniform allowances for members of the Division of Police are

127.13 ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER.
   (a)   The Animal Control Officer shall be appointed by the Chief of Police
and shall serve at the Chief’s pleasure.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the Animal Control Officer, and he/she shall
have the authority, to enforce the laws of the State of Ohio and the City of
Middleburg Heights relative to the licensing, impounding, boarding, treatment
and disposition of animals, livestock or poultry within the corporate limits;
however, no police or other officer of this City, charged with the
responsibility of enforcing the ordinances of this City and the laws of this
state, shall be relieved of such responsibility.
   (c)   The Animal Control Officer shall be provided with a badge designating
his/her office, and such other uniform, vehicles and equipment necessary to
carry out his/her duties. The Animal Control Officer is authorized to issue, on
a form provided by the City, a citation to any person found by him/her to be in
violation of the Codified Ordinances of the City, containing a notice to answer
the charge against him/her in the Berea Municipal Court or Middleburg Heights
Mayor’s Court within a reasonable length of time after the alleged violation.
The Animal Control Officer shall cause the original of the notice to be filed
with the Court, a duplicate copy to be filed with the record section of the
Police Department, and shall retain a duplicate copy in a file maintained by
him/her. The citation shall include pertinent information and shall be sworn to
as required by the general laws of the state in respect to a complaint charging
commission of the offense alleged in the citation to have been committed.
(Ord. 1978-84. Passed 9-26-78; Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
127.14 COMPENSATION OF NEW APPOINTEES.
   Any applicant for the position of policeman within the City, who is
appointed subsequent to June 1, 1981, and who has had prior full-time police
experience in any governmental unit or political subdivision of the State, may,
for pay purposes only, have his or her rate of compensation paid in accordance
with a step level of the applicable collective bargaining agreement that is
greater than Step 1 of the collective bargaining agreement as determined by the
Mayor, provided that such appointee has served a minimum of two years as a
policeman in such political subdivision or governmental unit of the State.
(Ord. 1981-110. Passed 7-28-81.)
127.15 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT.
   The position of Administrative Assistant is hereby established for the
purpose of assisting the administration of the Police Division. Such employees
will be appointed by the Police Chief and shall serve at his or her pleasure.
   (a)   There shall be no more than two full-time Administrative Assistants.
   (b)   There shall be no more than three part-time Administrative Assistants.
   (c)   Part-time Administrative Assistants shall not be entitled to any
fringe benefits such as paid holidays, paid vacations, paid sick leave,
longevity, hospitalization or the like.
(Ord. 2021-52. Passed 7-13-21; Ord. 2022-4. Passed 1-11-22; Ord. 2024-61.
Passed 9-10-24.)
127.16 NONRESIDENT SERVICE.
   The Mayor, Director of Public Safety, Chief of Police, Supervisor of the
Shift, or any one of them, is hereby empowered to order that police protection
be provided to another political subdivision without a contract.
(Ord. 1991-15. Passed 2-12-91.)
127.17 PART-TIME KENNEL ASSISTANTS.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of two part-time kennel
assistants to the Police Department. Such employees shall be appointed by the
Chief of Police to serve at his or her pleasure. The Police Chief shall
determine the times during which the services of such employees are required.
   (b)   Such employees shall not be entitled to any fringe benefits such as
paid holidays, paid vacations, paid sick leave, longevity, hospitalization or
the like.
   (c)   Salary Grade: 12.
(Ord. 2019-92. Passed 9-24-19.)
127.171 PART-TIME ANIMAL SHELTER MANAGER.
   There is hereby established the position of part-time Animal Shelter Manager
to the Police Department. Such employee shall be appointed by the Chief of
Police to serve at his or her pleasure. The Police Chief shall determine the
times during which the services of such an employee is required.
(Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
127.18 PART-TIME SCHOOL RESOURCE OFFICER.
   The position of part-time school resource officer is hereby established to
provide a physical secure presence for students, faculty, staff, and visitors
to schools located in the City of Middleburg Heights within the Berea City
School District.
   (a)   One such employee may be appointed by the Chief of Police to serve at
his or her pleasure and shall be designated to primarily work at the Berea-
Midpark Middle School for a maximum of 35 hours per week during school hours.
      (1)   Such employee shall receive hospitalization but shall not be
entitled to any other fringe benefits such as paid holidays, paid vacations,
paid sick leave, longevity.
      (2)   Salary Grade: 27.
      (3)   Such employee must have a current Ohio Peace Officers Training
Certification and valid Ohio Driver's License.
   (b)   Additional such employees shall be appointed by the Chief of Police to
serve at his or her pleasure, and shall work a flexible schedule up to 29 hours
per week during school hours.
      (1)   Such employees shall not be entitled to any fringe benefits such as
paid holidays, paid vacations, paid sick leave, longevity, hospitalization.
      (2)   Salary Grade: 27.
      (3)   Such employees must have a current Ohio Peace Officers Training
Certification and valid Ohio Driver's License.
(Ord. 2021-81. Passed 10-26-21; Ord. 2023-77. Passed 10-10-23.)
127.19 SCHOOL CROSSING GUARDS.
   There is hereby established the positions of part-time School Crossing
Guards to the Police Department. Such employees shall be appoionted by the
Chief of Police to serve at his or her pleasure. The Police Chief shall
determine the times during which the services of such employees are required.
(Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
127.20 SAFETY TOWN INSTRUCTOR.
   There is hereby established the position of part-time Safety Town Instructor
to the Police Department. Such employee shall be appoionted by the Chief of
Police to serve at his or her pleasure. The Police Chief shall determine the
times during which the services of such an employee are required.
(Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)

   There is hereby established in and for the City a Fire Division which shall
consist of one full-time Fire Chief, one full-time Assistant Chief/Captain, up
to three full-time Captains, up to four full-time Lieutenants and up to
eighteen full-time Firefighters.
(Ord. 1985-89. Passed 6-25-85; Ord. 2000-18. Passed 12-12-00; Ord. 2004-14.
Passed 2-10-04; Ord. 2020-19. Passed 2-25-20.)

129.10 COMPENSATION OF NEW APPOINTEES.
   Any applicant for the position of fireman within the City, who is appointed
subsequent to June 1, 1981, and who has had prior full-time firefighter

fireman in such political subdivision or governmental unit of the State.
(Ord. 1981-110. Passed 7-28-81.)
129.11 RECLASSIFICATION OF FIREFIGHTERS TO FIREFIGHTER/PARAMEDICS; EMPLOYMENT
REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   If, on the effective date of this section (Ordinance 1982-21, passed
February 23, 1982), there are employees employed in the classification of
firefighter, such employees shall conitnue to be employed in such
classification until their employment is terminated with the City. All
employees hired after the effective date of this section (Ordinance 1982-21,
passed February 23, 1982) shall be classified and employed as firefighter/
paramedic. For the purposes of satisfying the authorized number of employees
set forth in Section
129.01, firefighter positions continued under this section shall count as
firefighter/paramedics.
   (b)   Each new employee of the Division of Fire hired after the effective
date of this section shall be hired as a firefighter/paramedic.
      (1)   Each firefighter/paramedic position shall require that all
employees satisfactorily complete a probationary period of thirty-six months
prior to permanent appointment.
      (2)   Each newly hired employee must satisfactorily complete all training
required for certification as a paramedic and become certified by the Ohio
Board of Regents in addition to all training required for the position of
firefighter, in order to satisfactorily complete the probationary period and
become eligible for a permanent appointment.
      (3)   Each newly hired employee shall be required to maintain a valid
Board of Regents certification as a paramedic as a condition of continued
employment with the City.
      (4)   Failure to comply with this section shall constitute immediate
grounds for removal (dismissal) from employment with the Division of Fire and
the City. (Ord. 1982-21. Passed 2-23-82.)
129.12 NONRESIDENT SERVICE.
   The Mayor, Director of Public Safety, Chief of Fire, Supervisor of the
Shift, or any one of them, is hereby empowered to order that fire equipment and
firefighters be provided to another political subdivision without a contract.
(Ord. 1991-45. Passed 4-23-91.)
129.13 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANTS.
   (a)   There is hereby established the full-time position of Administrative
Assistant in the Fire Division. Such employee shall be appointed by the Fire
Chief and shall serve at his or her pleasure.
   (b)   There is hereby established the part-time position of Administrative
Assistant in the Fire Division. Such employee shall be appointed by the Fire
Chief and shall serve at his or her pleasure.
(Ord. 1996-48. Passed 6-11-96; Ord. 2024-41. Passed 5-14-24.)
129.14 TEMPORARY INCREASE IN STAFFING.
   When a retirement date is submitted by a member of the Fire Division other
than the Chief, and is accepted and confirmed, then the rank from which the
member is retiring and the rank(s) below, if any, may be temporarily increased
from the authorized staffing levels established in Section 129.01, by up to one
member, for no more than 120 days immediately preceding the retiring member's
retirement date.
(Ord. 2019-76. Passed 6-25-19.)

131.05 ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION.
   In addition to salary and office expenses otherwise provided by Council, the
Director of Law shall receive such reasonable compensation as is approved by
Council, upon bills duly rendered, for trips out of the County on business for
the City or its officials, and for handling or settlement of any and all
proceedings, including preparation thereof, in court (other than those criminal
matters prosecuted on behalf of the City) or before any board, commission or
other tribunal other than a board or commission of the City.
