733.09   Issuance and renewal of operator’s license.
733.10   Certificate required.
733.11   Revocation of licenses.
733.99   Penalty .
   CROSS REFERENCES
         Pandering obscenity - see GEN. OFF.
666.12 
         Outdoor display of motion pictures - see GEN. OFF.
666.17
733.01 DEFINITION OF PICTURE MACHINE.
   The term “picture machine”, when used in this chapter, means any machine or
device, either permanently located or portable in nature, operated by or with
the aid of electricity, or any other illuminant, and which is designed,
intended or used to project upon a screen or other surface, pictorial
representations through the use of any type of film, tape or other material or
equipment. (Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.02 SCOPE.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to theaters, auditoriums,
schools, churches, halls and such other exhibition or meeting rooms to which
the public, or any segment thereof, is admitted to view the showing of any
pictorial representations projected from a picture machine as hereinbefore
defined.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.03 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No picture machine shall be installed, maintained or operated within the
City except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter and such other
provisions of these Codified Ordinances relating to the installation and
construction of a booth for the enclosing of a picture machine as well as the
requirements relating to the contents, ventilation, doors, electrical
installations and signs thereof together with such requirements relating to the
location, construction and other safety regulations for theaters, exhibition or
meeting halls, auditoriums or other places of amusement.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.04 USE OF PICTURE MACHINES; MAGAZINES AND SHUTTERS.
   All picture machines within which combustible film is used shall be equipped
with incombustible magazines for receiving and delivering the films during the
operation of the machine. A shutter must be provided and placed in front of the
condenser of the machine, so arranged that it can be instantly closed by the
operator.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.05 FILMS WITHIN THE BOOTH.
   Films not in the picture machine, but within the booth enclosing the
machine, shall be kept in metal boxes with tightly fitting covers.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.06 HOT CARBONS.
   Hot carbons taken from the lamps used in the picture machines shall be
deposited in a metal receptacle provided in the booth for such purpose.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.07 LICENSED OPERATORS REQUIRED.
   Only licensed picture machine operators shall be employed or permitted to
operate any picture machine unless such picture machine is exhibited by and
incidental to the purposes of any charitable, religious, benevolent or
educational institution, public or private.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.08 APPLICATION FOR OPERATOR'S LICENSE.
   Application for a license shall be upon the form issued by the Director of
Public Service. Such application shall be granted if the Director finds that
the applicant is qualified to perform the work for which the application is
sought.
   Evidence that the applicant is currently licensed by any other city, county,
State or political subdivision thereof shall be sufficient evidence of
qualification so as to authorize the issuance of a license.
   Evidence of repeated violations of the Building Code or other ordinances
shall be sufficient evidence to disqualify the applicant from receiving the
license.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70; Ord. 1998-137. Passed 12-22-98.)
733.09 ISSUANCE AND RENEWAL OF OPERATORS' LICENSES.
   Upon application, any license required under this chapter shall be issued to
the applicant by the Director of Public Service upon payment by the applicant
of a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and the furnishing of a bond
as hereinafter provided.
Such license shall be issued for a period of one year from January 1 of the
year that it is issued and shall expire on December 31 next following the date
of issuance.
   Such license shall be renewed each year thereafter, for a like period, upon
the payment of a license fee of ten dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.10 CERTIFICATE REQUIRED.
   No individual, partnership or corporation shall be permitted to conduct the
business of moving picture exhibitions, as herein described, until he has
applied for and procured from the Director of Public Service a certificate that
the premises wherein the exhibitions are to be given and the apparatus used in
connection therewith are in compliance with the provisions of this chapter and
other relevant provisions of these Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.11 REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   The Director of Public Service shall have authority, and it shall be his
duty, to revoke the license issued to any person, firm or corporation for
conducting or maintaining picture machine exhibitions when he is satisfied that
such licensee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter or other
relevant provisions of these Codified Ordinances, provided, however, that
before revoking such license opportunity shall be given to such licensee to
correct such violations. (Ord. 1970-50. Passed 3-24-70.)
733.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
101.99 general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

(Ord. 1973-53. Passed 3-13-73.)

(Ord. 1973-195. Passed 11-27-73.)

CHAPTER 741
Transportation of Radioactive Materials
741.01   Purpose and definitions.
741.02   Permit required.
741.03   Notification of transport required.
741.04   Issuance of permit.
741.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Radiation control - see Ohio R.C. 3701.90 et seq.
      Atomic energy development activity - see Ohio R.C. 4163.01 et seq.
      Issuance of insurance policy for radiation risks - see Ohio R.C. 5729.07
741.01 PURPOSE AND DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   The purpose of this chapter is to provide minimum standards and
regulations that ensure the safe shipment and transportation of radioactive
materials through the City.
   (b)   As used in this chapter, the word "shall" is always mandatory and not
merely directory. In addition:
      (1)   "Radioactive materials" means any material or combination of
materials which spontaneously emits ionizing radiation. Materials in which the
estimated specific activity is not greater than 0.002 microcuries per gram of
material and in which the radioactivity is essentially uniformly distributed
are not considered to be radioactive materials.
      (2)   "Large quantity radioactive materials" means a quantity the
aggregate radioactivity of which exceeds that specified in 10 Code of Federal
Regulations (C.F.R.) Part 71, Section 71.4(f).
      (3)   "Curie" means an expression of the quantity of radiation in terms
of the number of atoms which disintegrate per second. A "curie" is that
quantity of radioactive materials which decays such that 37,000,000,000 atoms
disintegrate per second.
      (4)   "Millicurie" means one thousandth of a curie.
      (5)   "Motor vehicle" means any vehicle defined as a motor vehicle in
Section
402.22 of the Traffic Code.
      (6)   "Person" means any individual, partnership or corporation engaged
in the transportation of passengers or property, whether as a common, contract
or private carrier, or freight forwarder, as those terms are used in the
Interstate Commerce Act, as amended.
         (Ord. 1978-154. Passed 11-14-78.)
741.02 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   A permit, issued by the Director of Public Safety, shall be required
for the shipping or transportation of the following radioactive materials by
motor vehicle into, within, through or out of the City.
      (1)   Plutonium isotopes in any quantity and form exceeding two grams or
twenty curies, whichever is less;
      (2)   Uranium enriched in the isotope U-235 exceeding twenty-five atomic
percent of the total uranium content in quantities where the U-235 content
exceeds one kilogram;
      (3)   Any elements with an atomic number of eighty-nine or greater, the
activity of which exceeds twenty curies;
      (4)   Spent reactor fuel elements or mixed fission products associated
with such fuel elements, the activity of which exceeds twenty curies;
      (5)   Large quantity radioactive materials;
      (6)   Any quantity, arrangement and packaging combination of fissile
material specified by the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission as a
"Fissile Class III" shipment in 10 C. F.R. Part 71, Section 71.4(d)(3); or
      (7)   Any shipment or transportation of radioactive material that is
required by the appropriate regulating agency to be accomplished by an escort
for safety reasons.
   (b)   This section shall not apply to radioactive materials shipped or
transported by or for the United States Government for military or security
purposes or which are related to national defense.
(Ord. 1978-154. Passed 11-14-78.)
741.03 NOTIFICATION OF TRANSPORT REQUIRED.
   When those radioactive materials requiring a permit as specified in this
chapter are to be shipped or transported into, within, through or out of the
City, the shipper, carrier or person otherwise responsible shall first notify
the Director of Public Safety, on a form provided, two weeks prior to the date
of shipment. The form shall include the date of shipment, the type and quantity
of radioactive materials involved, the method of transportation, the route, the
starting point, the destination and such other information as such Director may
reasonably require. Any information which cannot be supplied two weeks prior to
shipment or transportation shall be supplied promptly by the person responsible
for such shipment or transportation when such information becomes available to
him. Nothing herein shall be construed as requiring the disclosure of any
defense information or restricted data as defined in the Atomic Energy Act of
1954 and the Energy Reorganization Act of 1974.
(Ord. 1978-154. Passed 11-14-78.)
741.04 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety shall not issue a permit to any person
for the shipment or transportation of those radioactive materials specified in
this chapter, unless:
      (1)   There is an indication that the radioactive material is or will be
containerized and packaged and that all warning labels are affixed to the outer
container holding the radioactive material and that the motor vehicle
transporting such material is in conformity with the regulations of the United
States Nuclear Regulatory Commission or other related Federal or State
agencies, regardless of whether the shipment is being made intracity,
intrastate or interstate; and
      (2)   There is an indication that the shipment or transportation of
radioactive materials is necessitated by urgent public policy or national
security interests which transcend public safety and health concerns of the
City.
         For the purposes of this paragraph:
         A.   An "urgent public policy" shall include medical and educational
interests.
         B.   An "urgent public policy" shall not include interests other than
medical and educational interests, unless expressly authorized in writing by
the United States Department of Transportation or by any other appropriate
Federal or State agency whose authorization may be required by the Director of
Public Safety. Such authorization shall state that the particular interest
involved is, in the opinion of the agency, permitted by Federal or State
regulations pertaining to the shipment or transportation of radioactive
materials and that the interest involved justifies the apparent risks resulting
from such shipment or transportation.
   (b)   Radioactive materials, which are permitted to be shipped or
transferred through the City pursuant to this chapter, shall be shipped or
transported through the City over such a route or at such a time of day as is
consistent with the health, safety and welfare of the public and the
convenience of the shipper or carrier, as the Safety Director of the City may
direct.
(Ord. 1978-154. Passed 11-14-78.)
741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000)
or imprisoned not more than six months, or both.
(Ord. 1978-154. Passed 11-14-78.)
CHAPTER 743
Licensing Contractors
743.01   Contractor defined.
743.02   License required; exceptions.
743.03   Work permit to be issued only to   licensed contractors.
743.04   Application and qualifications.
743.05   License fee and term.
743.06   Surety bond required.
743.07   License suspension or revocation.
743.08   Hearing of appeal.
743.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Licensing of plumbers and electricians - see Ohio R.C. 715.27
      Regional Dwelling House Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1305 
      Regional Building Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1307 
      Ohio Basic Building Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1309 
      National Electrical Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1311
743.01 CONTRACTOR DEFINED.
   "Contractor," as used in this chapter, means any individual, firm,
copartnership, corporation, association or other organization, or any
combination thereof, who or which, by himself or itself, or by or through
others, constructs, alters, repairs, adds to, subtracts from, reconstructs or
remodels any building, structure or appurtenance thereto, or who or which
undertakes or offers to undertake, or purports to have the capacity to
undertake, or submits a bid, to do so. The word "contractor" includes
subcontractor and specialty contractor, whose operation as such is the
performance of construction work requiring special skill and whose principal
contracting business involves the use of specialized building trades or crafts.
(Ord. 1978-167. Passed 11-28-78.)
743.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   No person shall engage in the business or act in the capacity of a
contractor without obtaining a license therefor. Such license shall be issued
in conformity with the provisions of this chapter by the Building Commissioner.
   No provision of this chapter shall be interpreted to require that the owner
of a one or two-family dwelling or individual row house shall be licensed to
personally perform work upon the premises occupied or to be occupied by such
owner as such owner's established residence.
   This chapter shall apply to officials or employees of the Municipality
engaged in Municipal work, or to officials or employees of public utilities in
such work for such public utilities as they are authorized by law to furnish or
provide.
(Ord. 1983-44. Passed 4-12-83.)
743.03 WORK PERMIT TO BE ISSUED ONLY TO LICENSED CONTRACTORS.
   No permit required by the provisions of the Building Code shall be issued
for work to be undertaken by contract except to a licensed contractor.
(Ord. 1978-167. Passed 11-28-78.)
743.04 APPLICATION AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   Application for a contractor’s license shall be made on forms provided by
the Building Commissioner and shall set forth the name of the applicant, his
age, his place of business, his experience in the work for which such license
is applied and such other information as the Commissioner may require in order
to determine the qualifications of such applicant for the work proposed to be
done. The Commissioner, in determining whether the applicant is qualified to
receive such license, may grant such license upon finding that the applicant
has been duly licensed by another municipality within the County, if the
Commissioner is satisfied that an adequate investigation or examination has
been made by such municipality of the applicant’s qualifications for the work
for which such license was issued.
(Ord. 1983-44. Passed 4-12-83.)
743.05 LICENSE FEE AND TERM.
   Upon being satisfied that the applicant is qualified and able to
satisfactorily do the work for which a license is applied, the Building
Commissioner shall issue a license to the applicant upon payment of a fee of
one hundred dollars ($100.00). The license shall expire 12 months after the
issue.
(Ord. 1988-49. Passed 8-9-88; Ord. 2005-79. Passed 6-28-05; Ord. 2009-83.
Passed 10-13- 09; Ord. 2014-71. Passed 11-11-14.)
743.06 SURETY BOND REQUIRED.
   Prior to the issuance of a license, the Building Commissioner shall require
an applicant to furnish a surety bond, to be approved as to form by the
Director of Law, guaranteeing full and faithful compliance by the applicant
with all the provisions of the Building Code and binding the surety thereon to
correct or abate any violation of the Building Code whenever the applicant
named as principal on such bond refuses, neglects or fails to correct or abate
such violation within a reasonable time limit as set by the Commissioner. The
bond shall indemnify the City and all other persons from injuries or damages
arising by reason of the applicant’s negligence or failure to properly perform
any work undertaken pursuant to such license. The bond for all contractors
shall be in the penal sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000).
(Ord. 1983-44. Passed 4-12-83; Ord. 2005- 79. Passed 6-28-05; Ord. 2019-32.
Passed 4-9-19.)
743.07 LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   The Building Commissioner may suspend or revoke any license issued under
this chapter for any of the following reasons:
   (a)   Misrepresentation of a material fact by the applicant in obtaining a
license or renewal thereof;
   (b)   Use of a license in obtaining permits for another person;
   (c)   Faulty or defective workmanship;
   (d)   Departure from or disregard of plans and specifications filed with the
application for a permit; or
   (e)   The noncompliance with or violation of any provision of the Building
Code.
      (Ord. 1983-44. Passed 4-12-83.)
743.08 HEARING OF APPEAL.
   A licensee whose license has been suspended or revoked may appeal such order
of suspension or revocation to the Board of Building Appeals. The appellant may
be represented by counsel at his own expense. The Board shall permit the
appellant and the Director of Public Service or the Building Commissioner to
call witnesses and introduce component testimony pertinent to a hearing of
appeal. The appeal shall be made in writing and filed with the secretary of the
Board within thirty days after the receipt of the notice or order. The Board
may affirm, reverse or modify any action taken by the Director of Public
Service or the Building Commissioner. (Ord. 1983-44. Passed 4-12-83.)
743.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, for which no penalty
is otherwise provided, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall
be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more
than sixty days, or both.
(Ord. 1978-167. Passed 11-28-78.)
CHAPTER 745
Tree Removal Services
745.01   Definitions.

coverage required.
745.03   Application; fee.

668

745.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Tree removal” means removal of a tree or trees from its location by
any means including cutting, sawing or digging.
   (b)   “Tree removal service” means a person or enterprise that engages in
the business of cutting or removing trees.
   (c)   “Tree” includes any tree with a caliper of five inches or more.
      (Ord. 2012-73. Passed 1-8-13.)
745.02 REGISTRATION, PROOF OF LIABILITY INSURANCE AND WORKERS COMPENSATION
COVERAGE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No tree removal service shall contract, either orally or in writing,
for tree removal without first obtaining a registration and providing proof of
liability insurance coverage and proof of workers compensation coverage in an
amount deemed sufficient by the Building Commissioner. (Ord. 2012-73. Passed 1-
8-13.)
745.03 APPLICATION; FEE.
   (a)   The application shall contain the name, address and principal place of
business or office of the applicant, together with a statement of the length of
time the applicant has been in business and his general experience or
knowledge.
   (b)   The registration shall be in effect for a period of one year, and the
fee shall be $75.00. (Ord. 2012-73. Passed 1-8-13.)
745.04 BOND FORFEITURE.
   Upon the Building Commissioner’s determination that the applicant has
violated any law or has failed to meet the minimum standards for contracting in
the City of Middleburg Heights the applicant’s registration shall be revoked.
(Ord. 2012-73. Passed 1-8-13.)
745.05 APPEAL.
   The decision of the Building Commissioner to revoke a registration may be
appealed to the Service Director, by written notice of such intention to appeal
filed with the Building Department within ten days of the revocation. The
decision of the Service Director shall be final. (Ord. 2012-73. Passed 1-8-13.)
