   Any person, partnership or corporation desiring to raze any primary building
in the City shall deposit with the Building and Zoning Director a bond of three
hundred dollars ($300.00) in cash conditioned upon the faithful and prompt
performance of such razing as described in the application. This amount shall
be returned to the depositor upon a determination by the Director, after
inspection, that the razing has been properly and satisfactorily completed. The
fee for razing a building or structure is fifty dollars ($50.00). If a building
is razed by means of burning by the Division of Fire in a drill duly scheduled
for the purpose of training and approved by the Mayor, no bond shall be
required, but a thirty dollar ($30.00) fee shall be charged for inspection of
the premises after razing. If an accessory building is razed in the City there
shall be charged twenty-five dollars $(25.00) as a fee for inspection after
razing.
   (i)   Additions or Remodeling of Commercial and Industrial Buildings. Any
new addition or remodeling of commercial and industrial buildings, structures
or projects:
      Base fee of                        $100.00
      Plus for every $1,000 of valuation               10.00
      (Ord. 2005-79. Passed 6-28-05.)
   (j)   Moving Excessively Large or Heavy Equipment or Devices.
      (1)   For moving on any public street or any portion thereof.
         A.   Where the object moved is under ten feet wide and not high enough
to interfere with overhead wires, lights, tree limbs, etc., and moved on a
standard truck or trailer at moderate speed with little or no interference to
normal traffic,
            the fee of                  $ 100.00
            Where the City must provide an escort
            or supervisor                  50.00 per hour
         B.   Where the object moved is over ten feet wide and moved on a
carry-all, truck or trailer at a continuous rate of speed and with a moderate
interruption of normal traffic,
            the fee of                  $100.00
            Where the City must provide an escort
            or supervisor                  50.00 per hour
      (2)   Moving without traversing any public street or any portion thereof.
         Base fee of                     $ 50.00
In addition to the above, at the discretion of the Director of Public Service,
additional fees, up to the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), may be
charged to cover extra supervision and inspections, according to the nature of
the work and the time involved.
The above fees or charges do not include any necessary charges which might be
made which might be entailed and occasioned by the moving.
All charges from public utilities involved, and occasioned by the moving, are
to be paid by the owner or mover. (The mover must provide the Director with an
adequate cash deposit or bond.)

construction or any other type of construction, the amount of cash deposit
shall be set by the Building and Zoning Director at a figure he deems adequate.
All deposits shall be subject to increase if the nature of the work warrants.
When all construction work is completed, all temporary office, tool and/or
storage sheds are removed and when the property involved has been restored to a
reasonable state of orderliness, then a final inspection shall be made.
         A.   Where work has been completed satisfactorily at the time of final
inspection any cash deposits will be refunded (with the exception of any
charges deemed necessary for extra inspections.)
         B.   If work is not satisfactorily completed within a specified time
given by the Director, in writing, the entire amount of the bond shall be
forfeited.

1303.11 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMITS.
   The Building Inspector or any Assistant Building Inspector is hereby
authorized to suspend or revoke permits for any construction in the City upon
the determination that any of the zoning, building or other ordinances, rules
or regulations of the City is being violated in connection with the
construction of such building. Upon being notified of such suspension or
revocation of a permit, no person shall in any manner continue construction
until such permit is reinstated by the Building Inspector.
(Ord. 1972-221. Passed 12-26-72.)
1303.12 ESTABLISHMENT OF LOT DRAINAGE PRIOR TO COMMENCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION.
   In all cases where the construction of buildings or structures in the City
requires, as incident to such construction, the installation of storm sewers,,
drains or swails, such storm sewers, drains or swails must be installed at the
rough finish grade prior to the commencement of construction of the structure.
(Ord. 1973-169. Passed 10-23-73.)
1303.99 GENERAL CODE PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Part Thirteen - Building Code or any
of the codes adopted or incorporated by reference in this Part Thirteen of
these Codified Ordinances, where no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be
fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than
six months, or both.
(Ord. 1973-195. Passed 11-27-73.)
CHAPTER 1305
Residential Code of Ohio For One, Two and Three-Family Dwellings

1305.01 RESIDENTIAL CODE OF OHIO ADOPTED.
   There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing rules and
regulations for the construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment,
use and occupancy, location and maintenance of one and two-family dwellings and
appurtenant structures, including permits and penalties, that certain building
code known as the Residential Building Code of Ohio for One, Two and Three-
Family Dwellings promulgated by the Ohio Board of Building Standards as amended
from time to time. (Ord. 2006-68. Passed 12-12-06.)
1305.02 FOOTER DRAINS.
   Any time a footer drain is required the applicant shall install bed footer
drains at the bottom elevation of footers on solid ground to insure flow of
water to the storm sewer connection. All pipe and fittings shall be connected
in the proper manner as prescribed in ASTM standards. Pipe shall be ASTM
standards D2726 (PVC only) in accordance with the specifications of the
Building and Zoning Director. After inspection of the drain tile and
downspouts, the foundation shall be backfilled to a height no less than two
feet below the approved finished grade. The back fill material shall be
limestone No. 57 only, the minimum size being three-quarter inch. The minimum
width of the backfill of gravel shall be two feet.
(Ord. 1990-12. Passed 2-13-90.)

1309.01 ADOPTION BY REFERENCE: APPLICATION OF OHIO PLUMBING CODE.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 731.231, there is hereby adopted by and for the
Municipality the Ohio Basic Building Code (OBBC), as adopted by the Ohio Board
of Building Standards, Department of Industrial Relations, as published in
Division 4101:2 of the Ohio Administrative Code (OAC), together with all
amendments, except as expressly modified in this chapter. The Ohio Basic
Plumbing Code (OBPC) contained within the Ohio Basic Building Code (OBBC) is
hereby made expressly applicable to both residential and commercial
construction in the City.
(Ord. 1989-19. Passed 4-11-89.)
   (b)   The BOCA National Building Code, 1990, Eleventh Edition, as well as
the BOCA National Mechanical Code, 1990, Seventh Edition, as published by
Building Officials and Code Administrators International, Inc., and as amended
by Chapter 4101:2-1 through 4101:2-51 of the Ohio Administrative Code, are
incorporated herein as fully as if set out in length.
1309.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Ohio Basic Building Code, as adopted in Section
1309.01, is to:
   (a)   Provide uniform standards and requirements for the erection,
construction, repair, alteration and maintenance of buildings, including
construction of industrialized units, such standards relating to the
conservation of energy, safety and sanitation of buildings for their intended
use and occupancy;
   (b)   Formulate such standards and requirements, so far as is practical, in
terms of performance objectives, so as to make adequate performance for the use
intended the test of acceptability;
   (c)   Permit, to the fullest extent feasible, the use of materials and
technical methods, devices and improvements, including the use of
industrialized units, which tend to reduce the cost of construction and
erection without affecting minimum requirements for the health, safety and
security of the occupants or users of buildings or industrialized units and
without preferential treatment of types or classes of materials or products or
methods of construction; and
   (d)   Encourage, so far as may be practical, the standardization of
construction practices, methods, equipment, material and techniques, including
methods employed to produce industrialized units. (OAC 4101:2-1-05)
1309.03 APPLICATION.
   The Ohio Basic Building Code, as adopted in Section
1309.01, applies to all buildings except as follows:
   (a)   Single-family, two-family and three-family dwelling houses which are
not constructed of industrialized units, except where the context specifies
mandatory applicability;
   (b)   Buildings owned by and used for a function of the United States
government;
   (c)   Existing buildings where their location, parts, equipment and other
items do not constitute a serious hazard unless otherwise regulated by the
provisions of Sections 4101:2-1-11 to 4101:2-1-13 of the Ohio Administrative
Code;
   (d)   Buildings constructed in accordance with plans which have been
approved prior to the effective date of the Ohio Basic Building Code;
   (e)   Buildings or structures which are incident to the use for agricultural
purposes of the land on which such buildings or structures are located,
provided such buildings or structures are not used in the business of retail
trade (see Ohio R.C. 3781.06 and 3781.061);
   (f)   Agricultural labor camps, as defined in Ohio R.C. 3733.41;
   (g)   Single-family, two-family and three-family detached dwelling houses
for which applications have been submitted to the Ohio Director of Human
Services pursuant to Ohio R.C. 5104.03 for the purposes of operating type A
family day-care homes, as defined in Ohio R.C. 5104.01;
   (h)   Single-family, two-family and three-family detached dwellings existing
on or before November 15, 1990, for which applications have been made to the
Ohio Director of Health pursuant to Ohio R.C. 3722.041 for the purpose of
operating adult group homes as defined in Ohio R.C. 3722.01; and
   (i)   Buildings or structures which are designed, constructed and maintained
in accordance with Federal standards and regulations and are used primarily for
Federal and State military purposes where the U.S. Secretary of Defense,
pursuant to 10 U.S.C. 2233(A)(1), (5) and (6) and 2237, has:
      (1)   Acquired, by purchase, lease or transfer, and constructs, expands,
rehabilitates or corrects and equips such buildings or structures as he or she
determines to be necessary to carry out the purposes of Chapter 133 of the
U.S.C.;
      (2)   Contributed to the State amounts for the acquisition, construction,
expansion, rehabilitation and conversion by the State of such additional
buildings or structures as he or she determines to be required because of the
failure of existing facilities to meet the purposes of Chapter 133 of the
U.S.C.; or
      (3)   Contributed to the State such amounts for the construction,
alteration or rehabilitation of arms storage rooms as he or she determines to
be required to meet a change in U.S. Department of Defense standards related to
the safekeeping of arms. (OAC 4101:2-1-09)
1309.04 COMPLIANCE; VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   No owner or any other person shall construct, erect, build or equip
any building or structure to which the Ohio Basic Building Code is applicable,
or make any addition thereto or alteration thereof, except in the case of
repairs or maintenance that does not affect the construction, sanitation,
safety or any other vital feature of such building or structure, without
complying with this chapter, Ohio R.C. Chapters 3781 and 3791 or the Ohio Basic
Building Code, or fail to comply with any lawful order issued pursuant thereto.
(ORC 3791.01, 3791.02)
   (b)   No architect, builder, engineer, plumber, carpenter, mason,
contractor, subcontractor, foreman or employee shall violate or assist in
violating any of the provisions of this chapter, Ohio R.C. Chapters 3781 and
3791 or the Ohio Basic Building Code, or fail to comply with any lawful order
issued pursuant thereto.
(ORC 3791.01, 3791.03)
   (c)   No owner or any other person shall proceed with the construction,
erection, alteration or equipment of any building or structure to which the
Ohio Basic Building Code is applicable without complying with this chapter and
the plan and specification submission and processing requirements of the
Municipality, and until plans or drawings, specifications and data have been
approved or the industrialized unit has been inspected at the point of origin.
(ORC 3791.04)
1309.05 CHANGE OF USE; MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   Change of Use. The use of a building shall not be changed, as defined
in the Ohio Basic Building Code, unless or until the building and the building
service equipment therein conform to the requirements of such Code for
buildings of the proposed new use group classification and to Municipal zoning
requirements. (OAC 4101:2-1-11)
   (b)   Maintenance. Buildings and building service equipment shall be
maintained so as to comply with the Code, except that when a serious hazard
does not exist no change in construction and no additional facilities are
required except as may be made necessary by a change of use under subsection
(a) hereof. (OA C 4101: 2-1-13)
1309.06 ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   When the Municipality finds that work or equipment is contrary to this
chapter, approved plans therefor or the Ohio Basic Building Code, notice in
writing shall be sent to the owner of the building involved or his or her
agent. The notice shall state where and in what respect the work or equipment
does not conform to such lawful requirements and shall specify a reasonable
period of time in which to conform.
(OAC 4101:2-1-34)
   (b)   Prior to enforcement of Ohio R.C. Chapters 3781 and 3791, or any rules
adopted pursuant thereto, including the Ohio Basic Building Code, as adopted in
Section
1309.01, by any remedy, civil or criminal, the Municipality shall issue an
adjudication order within the meaning of Ohio R.C. 119.06 to 119.13 or a stop
work order as provided in Section 4101:2-1-36 of the Ohio Administrative Code.
   (c)   Every adjudication order shall cite the law or rules directly involved
and shall specify what appliances, site preparations, additions or alterations
to structures, plans, materials, assemblages or procedures are necessary for
the same to comply with Ohio R.C. Chapters 3781 and 3791 and/or any rules
adopted pursuant thereto, including the provisions of the Ohio Basic Building
Code adopted in Section
1309.01.
   (d)   The order shall include notice to the party of the procedure for
appeal and right to a hearing if requested within thirty days of the mailing of
the notice. The notice shall also inform the party that at the hearing he or
she may be represented by counsel, present his or her arguments or contentions
orally or in writing, and present evidence and examine witnesses appearing for
or against him or her.
   (e)   Upon the issuance of any order provided for herein or in Section 4101:
2-1-36 of the Ohio Administrative Code, the person receiving such order shall
cease work upon the site preparations or structure to be constructed, or, in
the case of an industrialized unit, the installation of the unit. or shall
cease using the appliance, materials, assemblages or manufactured product
identified in the order until such time as the appeal provided for in
accordance with the provisions of Ohio R. C. 3781.19, and all appeals from such
hearing, have been completed, or the order herein has been released.
(OAC 4101:2-1-35)
   (f)   Failure to cease work after receipt of a stop work order as provided
in Section 4101:2-1-36 of the Ohio Administrative Code is hereby declared to be
a public nuisance.
(OAC 4101:2-1-36)
1309.07 FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.
   At least one copy of the Codes adopted in Section
1309.01, is on file with the Clerk of Council for inspection by the public. At
least one copy of such Codes is also on file in the County Law Library. In
addition, the Clerk of Council shall keep copies of such Codes available for
distribution to the public, at cost.
1309.08 CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   (a)   Whenever a provision of the Ohio Basic Building Code, as adopted in
Section
1309.01, conflicts with a provision of the Ohio Fire Code or any other order,
standard or rule of the Ohio Department of Commerce, Division of State Fire
Marshal, the provision of the Ohio Basic Building Code shall control, except
that rules adopted and orders issued by the Fire Marshal pursuant to Ohio R.C.
Chapter 3741 prevail in the event of a conflict.
(OAC 4101:2-1-04(13); ORC 3781.11(D))
   (b)   Whenever a provision of the Ohio Basic Building Code, as adopted in
Section
1309.01, conflicts with a provision of any other standard technical code
adopted by the Municipality, other than as provided in subsection (a) hereof,
or any ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of Council, the stricter
standard shall control.
   (c)   When a special provision is made in a use group classification of the
Ohio Basic Building Code and is inconsistent with a general provision of the
Ohio Basic Building Code relating to buildings generally, the special provision
governs, unless it appears that the provisions are cumulative. (OAC 4101:2-1-
07)
1309.09 AMENDMENTS.
   The Ohio Basic Building Code, as adopted herein, is hereby amended as
follows:
   Table 4101:2-51-35 Water Distribution Pipe.
   Water supply pipes for plumbing systems shall be of galvanized wrought iron
or steel, brass, copper or cast iron, with brass, cast iron, galvanized
malleable iron or copper fittings. No pipe or fittings that have been used for
other purposes shall be used for distributing water. Copper tube underground
shall be of Type "K." Copper tube for water lines above ground shall be of Type
"L" or heavier. Stainless steel tubing for water lines shall be Grade II, Type
R-K and R-L, welded red brass tubing may be used for water lines above and
below ground and Type R-M may be used only above ground. Welded and drawn
copper tubing and welded brass (copper alloy) tubing may be used above ground
only.
Table 4101:2-51-05(A)
   Only plastic pipe of the PVC type is approved and the same shall be
permitted in all plumbing installations in commercial and residential
construction, except for water supply lines which shall be only of galvanized
wrought iron or steel, brass, copper or cast iron. Such PVC plastic pipe shall
be as listed in the approved standards of Table 4101:2-51-05(A) of the Ohio
Basic Plumbing Code (OBPC) which is part of the Ohio Basic Building Code
(OBBC).
   All materials for plumbing systems as approved herein shall be cast iron,
brass, copper, PVC-type plastic only or other material approved in the Ohio
Basic Plumbing Code, Section 4101:2-51, Table 4101:2-51-05(A).
   The installation in plumbing systems of plastic pipe not listed in Table
4101:2-51-05(A) shall also be permitted in accordance with the following
requirements and specifications:
   A.   Plastic plumbing pipe to be used in the interior of buildings or
dwellings shall be D-2665-78 PVC or Schedule 40 or equivalent in accordance
with approved standards for plumbing materials listed in Table 4101:2-51-05(A)
of the OBBC.
   B.   Plastic plumbing pipe for use in exterior installations, excluding
footer drains (subsoil drains), shall be C-3034-78 PVC or Schedule 35 or
equivalent in accordance with approved standards for plumbing materials listed
in Table 4101:2-51-05(A) of the OBPC.
   C.   Plastic plumbing pipe to be used for footer drains (subsoil drains)
shall be 2726 PVC 1,500 lbs. crush or equivalent in accordance with the
specifications of the City Engineer.
   D.   All downspout fillings above grade shall include a standard adapter to
accept leader drains.
      (Ord. 1984-53. Passed 5-22-84.)
1309.10 FOOTER DRAINS.
   Any time a footer drain is required the applicant shall install bed footer
drains at the bottom elevation of footers on solid ground to insure flow of
water to the storm sewer connection. All pipe and fittings shall be connected
in the proper manner as prescribed in A.S.T.M. standards. Pipe shall be
A.S.T.M. standards D2726 (PCV only) in accordance with the specifications of
the Building and Zoning Director. After inspection of the drain tile and
downspouts, the foundation shall be backfilled to a height no less than two
feet below grade. The backfill material shall be limestone No. 57 only, the
minimum size being three-quarter inch. The minimum width of the backfill of
gravel shall be two feet.
(Ord. 1990-12. Passed 2-13-90.)
1309.99 PENALTY; EQUITABLE REMEDIES.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, including any provision of the Ohio Basic Building Code adopted in
Section
1309.01, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months,
or both, for each offense. Unless otherwise provided, a separate offense shall
be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance
occurs or continues.
   (b)   The application of the penalty provided in subsection (a) hereof shall
not be deemed to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions, or the
application of any other equitable remedy, including abatement of the nuisance
referred to in Section
1309.06(f).

CHAPTER 1323
Yard Grades
1323.01   Permit required.
1323.02   Application and fee.
1323.03   Method of establishing grade.
1323.04   Grade required for building   permit.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Grading in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1111.05(b)
      Grading and seeding lands allocated for public use - see P. & Z.
1111.13 
      Grade changes - see BLDG. Ch.
1337 
      Landscaping and lawn services - see BLDG. Ch.
1347
1323.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No building will be erected within the Municipality until the owner and/or
contractor thereof shall apply for and secure a yard grade permit.
(Ord. 1976-119. Passed 7-13-76.)
1323.02 APPLICATION AND FEE.
   The application for such yard grade permit will be made to the Building and
Zoning Director on forms furnished by the Director. In addition, the applicant
shall submit topographic maps as required by the Director or the City Engineer.
All elevations on such topographic maps shall be referenced to U.S. Geodetic
Survey Data. The fee for the yard grade permit shall be in accordance with the
following schedule and is payable when the application for such permit is made.
 
Type of Structure                     Fee
1. Single family residential          $385.00
2. Two or more single family attached $260.00 plus
                                      $125.00 additional for each unit
                                      $500.00 base fee for each building of
                                      5,000 square feet or less of foot print
3. Apartments, commercial and         area, plus
industrial                            $50.00 additional per 1,000 square feet
                                      or fraction thereof over 5,000 square
                                      feet
 
(Ord. 1994-3. Passed 2-22-94; Ord. 2001-3. Passed 1-9-01.)
1323.03 METHOD OF ESTABLISHING GRADE.
   Yard grades are to be established throughout the Municipality by the
Engineer. The Engineer will be paid for his or her services at the rate of
three hundred eight dollars ($308.00) per yard grade and at the rate of eighty
dollars ($80.00) for reinspection per yard grade required because of
nonconformity by the owner and/or contractor.
   In establishing the yard grade the Engineer shall take the following factors
into consideration:
   (a)   The overall area grading plan;
   (b)   The grade of the streets on which the lot or the land exists; in the
event that the street is not then in existence, the grade of the street as
proposed;
   (c)   The existing grade and/or contour of the lot and/or contour of
adjacent properties;
   (d)   The setback and location of the proposed building or structure on the
lot;
   (e)   Any other physical factors usually considered in conformity with good
engineering and construction practices.
   The Engineer shall indicate the yard grade as determined by him or her by
means of suitably marked stakes set near the property sideline at locations to
be determined by the Engineer. The Engineer shall in addition, indicate the
yard grade or other reference mark on some nearby fixed object such as a
telephone pole or fireplug. The Engineer shall also pick and approve the
elevation of the first floor joist plate of the proposed building or structure,
in accordance with the plans submitted by the owner and/or contractor. Such
elevation shall not be in excess of 24 above the highest point of the yard
grade at the building as established by the Engineer except in the case of
split level designed houses, in which event such elevation shall not be in
excess of 48 inches above the highest point of the yard grade.
(Ord. 1994-3. Passed 2-22-94; Ord. 2001-3. Passed 1-9-01.)
1323.04 GRADE REQUIRED FOR BUILDING PERMIT.
   (a)   The yard grade and elevation of the first floor joist plate as
determined by the Engineer shall become a part and condition of the building
permit issued by the Building and Zoning Director for the proposed building or
structure, and the building or structure shall conform and be constructed in
accordance with these conditions. The owner and/or contractor shall not
continue with the construction of the building until an inspection is made by
the Engineer of the footer forms prior to pouring of the footer, of the
completed foundation, of the first floor joist plate and of the final grade. If
upon each inspection by the Engineer it is found that such construction
conforms to the approval granted, then permission will be given to proceed. If,
however, the owner and/or contractor has varied from the established grade and
plate elevation, then the owner and/or contractor must pay an additional permit
fee of one hundred ninety dollars ($190.00). He or she must then make the
necessary corrections to conform to the established grade and plate elevation
before any further work will be permitted.
(Ord. 1994-3. Passed 2-22-94; Ord. 2001-3. Passed 1-9-01.)
   (b)   The Engineer shall also inspect the yard grade after completion of
landscaping and shall verify that it conforms to the established grade. In the
event that the Engineer determines upon final inspection after landscaping that
the owner and/or contractor has varied from the established grade, the owner
and/or contractor shall make the necessary corrections to conform to the
established grade.
(Ord. 1976-119. Passed 7-13-76.)
CHAPTER 1325
Swimming Pools
1325.01   Definitions.
1325.02   Compliance required.
1325.03   Distance between pool and property lines.
1325.04   Barrier required.
1325.05   Conformance to natural grade.
1325.06   Drainage.
1325.07   Illumination.
1325.08   Pool interior surfaces and filtration.
1325.09   Permit required; fee.
1325.10   Appeal on refusal to issue permit.
1325.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCE
   Board of Zoning and Building Code Appeals - see CHTR.
10.03
1325.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Outdoor Swimming Pool(s)” shall mean an artificial water pool of
steel, masonry, concrete, aluminum or plastic construction located out of
doors, which has a square foot water surface area of three hundred square feet
or more, or a depth at any point of more than two feet, or both.
   (b)   “Structural barrier” shall mean a structure that blocks passage.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61; Ord. 2009-34. Passed 4-28-09.)
1325.02 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No permanent or temporary swimming pool which is not enclosed to a permanent
building or like structure shall be constructed or maintained in the
Municipality unless and until the requirements and conditions hereinafter
enumerated are complied with.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.03 DISTANCE BETWEEN POOL AND PROPERTY LINES.
   Every pool hereafter built must be so located upon the lot or parcel as to
allow a safe distance between the pool and the property lines, so that children
of tender age can be readily observed while approaching or in the vicinity of
the pool. A distance of ten feet from each property side line and rear line and
ten feet to the rear of the main building to which the pool is accessory shall
be presumed a minimum safe distance for such purpose.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.04 BARRIER REQUIRED.
   Outdoor Swimming Pools, hot tubs and spas, containing water more than 24
inches (610 mm) in depth shall be completely surrounded by a fence or
structural barrier at least 48 inches (1219 mm) in height above the finished
ground level measured on the outside of the structural barrier. Some effective
means must be provided to deny access to the pool, spa or hot tub when not in
use or a responsible person is not in attendance. No existing pool enclosure
shall be removed, replaced or changed in a manner that reduces its
effectiveness as a safety barrier.
   (a)   Gates and doors in such structural barriers shall be self-closing and
self- latching. Where the self-latching device is less than 54 inches (1372 mm)
above the bottom of the gate, the release mechanism shall be located on the
pool side of the gate. Self-closing and self-latching gates shall be maintained
such that the gate will positively close and latch when released from an open
position of 6 inches (152 mm) from the gatepost.
   (b)   Where an above-ground pool structure is used as a structural barrier
or where the structural barrier is mounted on the top of the pool structure and
the means of access is a ladder or steps, then the ladder or steps shall be
surrounded by a structural barrier or shall be capable of being secured, locked
or removed to prevent access.
   (c)   Where a wall of a dwelling serves as part of the structural barrier,
all doors with direct access to the pool through that wall shall be equipped
with an alarm which produces an audible warning when the door and its screen,
if present, are opened. The alarm shall sound continuously for a minimum of
thirty seconds immediately after the door is opened and be capable of being
heard throughout the house during normal household activities. The alarm shall
automatically reset under all conditions. The alarm shall be equipped with a
manual means, such as a touchpad or switch, to temporarily deactivate the alarm
for a single opening. Such deactivation shall last for not more than fifteen
sounds. The deactivation switch(es) shall be located at least 54 inches (1372
mm) above the threshold of the door.
   (d)   Pools, spas or hot tubs which use a safety cover for a structural
barrier shall comply with the American Society for Testing and Materials - F
1346 Performance Specification for safety covers.
(Ord. 1992-2. Passed 1-14-92; Ord. 2009-34. Passed 4-28-09.)
1325.05 CONFORMANCE TO NATURAL GRADE.
   Every permanent swimming pool, constructed within an excavation in the
ground, hereafter constructed or created must substantially conform to the
natural grade of the surrounding land, and no part thereof, other than a diving
board or similar equipment, and the fence referred to in Section
1325.04, shall be higher than such grade.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.06 DRAINAGE.
   Every pool shall be so constructed that it can be drained into a Municipal
storm sewer or shall have a sump located in its deepest part, for the purpose
of pumping out all of the water into a storm sewer opening, sump well or other
adequate drain opening, approved by the Building Inspector. All drain water
must be conducted to its proper discharge point by means of tightly sealed
tile, pipe or hose. Under no circumstances shall any water from the pool or
from its use be permitted to drain towards or on to any adjoining properties.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.07 ILLUMINATION.
   If flood or other artificial light is used to illuminate the pool at night,
none of the lights shall be used after 10:30 p.m. local time, and all noise in
connection with pool activity must cease, if the pool is located within two
hundred feet of any building used for dwelling purposes. The lights shall also
be shielded to direct light only on the pool.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.08 POOL INTERIOR SURFACES AND FILTRATION.
   All swimming pools shall have smooth interior surfaces that can be readily
kept clean. When in use pools shall, at all times, be kept free of leaves,
debris, wood or any other materials which might endanger the safety or health
of the users.
   All swimming pools having a capacity of ten thousand gallons of water or
more shall be equipped with a filtration unit of sufficient size and capacity
and also a chlorination unit to insure healthful operation and maintenance of
the pool.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.09 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   No pool regulated by this chapter shall be hereafter constructed or
established unless a permit to do so is first obtained from the Inspector of
Buildings. A fee shall be charged for the issuance thereof, as outlined in
Chapter 1303.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.10 APPEAL ON REFUSAL TO ISSUE PERMIT.
   A refusal by the Inspector of Buildings to issue a permit as provided in
Section
1325.09, may be appealed in writing within ten days after such refusal to the
Board of Appeals, as provided for in other cases of appeals thereto. The Board
of Appeals shall then, in accordance with its rules of procedure, investigate
such application and refusal, and render final judgment based upon whether, in
its opinion, the provisions of this chapter have been and will be complied
with.
(Ord. 1961-30. Passed 5-23-61.)
1325.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 1973-195. Passed 11-27-73.)
CHAPTER 1327
Commercial Air Conditioning

1327.01 DEFINITION.
   "Commercial establishment" for the purposes of this chapter shall mean any
building or structure, whether temporary or permanent, or any part of a
building or structure which is not used solely for the housing and feeding
without charge of the inhabitants of such building or structure. (Ord. 1954-78.
Passed 11-8-54.)
1327.02 TYPE OF AIR CONDITIONER RESTRICTED.
   Air conditioning units requiring the use of water hereafter installed in any
commercial establishment within this Municipality must be equipped with a
system to provide for the recirculation and re-use within the unit of the water
originally used by the unit for cooling purposes, and the installation of any
other type of unit is hereby prohibited within the Municipality. (Ord. 1954-78.
Passed 11-8-54.)
1327.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 1973-195. Passed 11-27-73.)
CHAPTER 1329
Temporary Portable Structures
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Ordinance 2012-27, passed April 24, 2012, repealed former
Chapter 1329 Garbage Disposal Units and enacted new Chapter 1329 Temporary
Portable Structures as written in Ordinance 2012-20, passed March 27, 2012.
1329.01   Definitions.
1329.02   Portable storage containers.
1329.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Portable storage container” means any device, container, enclosure or
structure, either wheeled trailers or containers carried on motor vehicles or
trailers, commonly used to store home furnishings, and other personal items on
a temporary basis during a time of home repair, construction, renovation or
relocation. Portable storage containers do not include self-propelled
registered motor vehicles and may not be used as habitation for humans or
animals, or for the storage of commercial/industrial materials.
      (Ord. 2012-20. Passed 3-27-12.)
1329.02 PORTABLE STORAGE CONTAINERS.
   (a)   Permit Required. No portable storage container shall be constructed,
erected, or placed upon any residential property without first obtaining a
permit from the Building Department.
   (b)   Permit Fee. The fee for a portable storage container permit shall be
twenty dollars ($20.00).
   (c)   Application Requirements. Applications for a portable storage
container permit shall be in writing on forms provided by the Building
Department and state the following:
      (1)   Name and address of the owner of the property.
      (2)   Name and address of the applicant.
      (3)   Description of the portable storage container, including size and
dimension.
      (4)   A site plan to scale showing the location of the portable storage
container must be submitted to the Building Department and approved by the
Building Commissioner or designee.
   (d)   Restrictions. All portable storage containers must comply with the
following:
      (1)   A portable storage container permit shall be valid for a period of
thirty days and shall authorize the construction, erection or placement on the
property described in the application. When necessary, a portable storage
container permit may be extended an additional thirty days with approval by the
Building Commissioner or designee.
      (2)   Portable storage containers are only permitted on a lot containing
a lawfully existing residential dwelling.
      (3)   Only one portable storage container shall be placed on a lot at one
time.
      (4)   Portable storage containers must be located on a paved area unless
located on a residential construction project where a driveway is not yet
installed, in which case the portable storage container shall be located in the
proposed driveway location.
      (5)   Portable storage containers shall be located entirely on the
owner’s lot as close to the residence as possible, not blocking any site lines.
      (6)   No part of any portable storage container shall be located on any
public property or in the right-of-way.
      (7)   Any portable storage container constructed, erected or placed upon
property shall comply with all applicable provisions of the Middleburg Heights
Codified Ordinances.
         (Ord. 2012-20. Passed 3-27-12.)
CHAPTER 1331
Moving of Buildings
   EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter, previously titled "House Moving, " was repealed
in its entirety and re-enacted by Ordinance 1976-169, passed October 26, 1976.
1331.01   Definition.
1331.02   Prohibiting moving of buildings.
1331.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Blocking or obstructing streets - see TRAF.
412.01
      Sidewalk and street obstructions; damage or injury - see GEN. OFF.
660.23
1331.01 DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, "building" means a structure designed, built or
occupied as a shelter or other enclosure for persons, animals or property and
used for residential, business, mercantile, storage, commercial, industrial,
institutional, assembly, educational or recreational purposes, excluding motor
vehicles licensed as such by the appropriate governmental authority. Any
structure, the outside dimensions of which are all less than ten feet in width,
ten feet in length and fourteen feet in height, including the moving facility,
is not included in this definition. (Ord. 1976-169. Passed 10-26-76.)
1331.02 PROHIBITING MOVING OF BUILDINGS.
   No person shall within the City, move any building over, along or across any
highway, street or alley or across private property lines not owned by such
person.
(Ord. 1976-169. Passed 10-26-76.)
1331.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000) and imprisoned not more than six months or both.
(Ord. 1976-169. Passed 10-26-76.)
CHAPTER 1333
Dangerous Structures
   EDITOR'S NOTE: As part of the 1976 updating and revision of these Codified
Ordinances the provisions of this chapter were edited and reprinted so as to be
consistent with changes made in the City Charter.
1333.01   Abatement required.
1333.02   Notice by Building Commissioner.
1333.03   Noncompliance; remedy of City.
1333.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Dangerous, abandoned excavations, oil or gas wells, or buildings - see
GEN. OFF.
660.21 
      Building Department and Inspectors - see BLDG. Ch.
1301
1333.01 ABATEMENT REQUIRED.
   The owner or person having the charge or management of any lot or parcel of
land within the City limits upon which any building or other structure or
anything attached or connected thereto which is so unsafe as to endanger any
person or property or is unsecured or structurally defective, shall cause the
same to be made safe and secure or taken down and removed. The continuance or
maintenance of such a condition is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is
prohibited. (Ord. 1971-118. Passed 11-23-71.)
1333.02 NOTICE BY BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   Upon the determination of the Building Commissioner that such a condition as
described in Section
1333.01 exists, a notice to so repair, secure or take down and remove shall be
sent to the owner or person having the charge or management of such lot or
parcel of land, either by certified mail directed to such person or by posting
a copy of such notice on the premises and advertising a copy of such a notice
for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the County.
(Ord. 1983-47. Passed 4-12-83.)
1333.03 NONCOMPLIANCE; REMEDY OF CITY.
   Whenever such building or other structure or anything attached or connected
to any such lot has not been repaired, secured or taken down and removed within
twenty days from final service of such notice, the Building Commissioner shall
provide for the repairing, securing or taking down and removing as specified in
the notice to the owner or person having the charge or management of such lot
or parcel of land. The total cost therefor, as provided in Ohio R.C. 715.261
shall, if not paid within thirty days, be certified by the Clerk of Council to
the County Auditor to be placed upon the tax duplicate for collection in the
same manner as other taxes and assessments are collected. (Ord. 1971-118.
Passed 11-23-71.)
1333.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1303.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided. )
CHAPTER 1335
Debris from Grading, Excavation or Construction
1335.01   Permit and deposit required; deposit waiver.
1335.02   Cleaning by City; costs deducted from deposit.
1335.03   Additional deposit to cover City costs.
1335.04   Permit fees deducted; balance returned after completion.
1335.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Construction work, materials delivery, prohibited hours - see GEN. OFF.
648.10 
      Street openings - see S. & P.S. Ch.
901 
      Grade changes - see BLDG. Ch.
1337
1335.01 PERMIT AND DEPOSIT REQUIRED; DEPOSIT WAIVER.
   (a)   Prior to the commencement of grading, excavating or construction work
on other than City property, the owner or lessee of the property or the
contractor engaged for either grading, excavating or construction work thereon,
shall obtain a permit to do so and, as a condition precedent to the issuance of
such permit, shall make a deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150. 00) for a
single-family residential type of use or construction and one thousand dollars
($1,000) for an apartment, commercial or other type. Such a permit shall be
obtained from and a deposit made with the Department of Public Service and
shall be in addition to the other permits which are required before commencing
such work.
   (b)   If at any one time any depositor constructing single-family homes has
on deposit the sum of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for work being done
on any one street, the Director of Public Service, while such amount still
remains undepleted by charges including those which have been incurred under
the provisions of Section
1335.04, may direct the issuance of further permits for additional proposed
work on the same street as provided herein to such depositor without the
necessity of further deposits, except in the nature of permit fees. Such a
waiver of deposit, however, shall not be made to anyone who has in the past
violated any of the provisions of this chapter. The application for the
issuance of such permit shall specify the amount of material to be removed from
the construction site and the location to which such material is to be
transported. In the event that it is determined that such material must be
transported over State or Federal highways within the City, the applicant for
such permit shall post a cash bond in an amount satisfactory to the City
Engineer to guarantee the repair of any damage or destruction to the City's
roadways caused as a result of the material transfer. Trucks transporting such
excavation fill material upon roads other than those designated as truck routes
under Section
440.01 of the Traffic Code should have no more than two axles. (Ord. 1973-61.
Passed 3-27-73.)
1335.02 CLEANING BY CITY; COSTS DEDUCTED FROM DEPOSIT.
   During the progress of any such grading, excavating or construction, as set
forth in Section
1335.01, it shall be the duty of the owner and/or lessee and/or the contractor
to keep the street pavements, tree lawns and sidewalks clean of all dirt and
other debris caused by or arising from such work. In default thereof, the
Department of Public Service shall perform such cleaning and the charges
therefor shall be deducted from the required deposit. Charges are to include
labor, material, equipment and time, to and from the job site. Time is to be
computed from the departure from the service garage to the job site and back
again at no less than thirty dollars ($30.00) per hour.
(Ord. 1973-61. Passed 3-27-73.)
1335.03 ADDITIONAL DEPOSIT TO COVER CITY COSTS.
   Should the City perform any such cleaning referred to in Section
1335.02 during the progress of the work and the charge of the cost thereof is
deducted from the deposit in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or in
excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) in the event that the deposit was one
thousand dollars ($1,000), the depositor shall immediately make an additional
deposit so that the full amount of the required original deposit is maintained.
Should such owner and/or lessee and/or contractor fail or refuse to make such
additional deposit, the Director of Public Service or the Building Inspector
shall stop all further grading, excavating or construction work on the property
until such additional deposit is made.
(Ord. 1973-61. Passed 3-27-73.)
1335.04 PERMIT FEES DEDUCTED; BALANCE RETURNED AFTER COMPLETION.
   After completion of such work and after determination upon inspection by the
Department of Public Service that such areas are free of dirt and other debris,
such deposit less the cost of the cleaning work performed by the City and less
the ten dollar ($10.00) permit fee for residential-type and/or twenty-five
dollar ($25.00) permit fee for apartment, commercial or other type of use or
construction, shall be returned to the depositor thereof, provided that the
Building Inspector, in work involving provisions of the Building Code and the
Zoning Code, has given his final inspection and approval of all of the work and
has issued a certificate of occupancy for the premises as provided for in the
Zoning Code.
   The ten dollar ($10.00) and/or twenty-five dollar ($25.00) permit fee shall
be payable and deducted from the deposit provided for in Section
1335.01 at the time the permit is issued and represents the costs to the City
of making inspections while the work progresses.
(Ord. 1973-61. Passed 3-27-73.)
1335.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 1973-61. Passed 3-27-73.)
CHAPTER 1337
Grade Changes
1337.01   Definitions.
1337.02   Prohibition of certain grade   changes.
1337.03   Elevation changes; permit required.
1337.04   Application for permit; fee.
1337.05   Inspection, report and certification by City Engineer.
1337.06   Maintaining grade lines established by City.
1337.07   Use of foundry sand as land fill.
1337.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Grading in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1111.05(b)
      Grading and seeding lands allocated for public use - see P. & Z.
1111.13 
      Yard grades - see BLDG. Ch.
1323 
      Debris from grading, excavation or construction - see BLDG. Ch.
1335
1337.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Natural watercourse" means any river, creek, brook or branch and the
flood plain thereof.
   (b)   "Lot" means any sublot in a recorded subdivision.
   (c)   "Parcel of land" means any parcel of land other than a lot within the
City.
      (Ord. 1973-75. Passed 4-10-73.)
1337.02 PROHIBITION OF CERTAIN GRADE CHANGES.
   No person shall, by excavation, filling or other means, change the grade of
any lot or parcel of land within the City in such manner as to:
   (a)   Create a nuisance upon such property, by obstruction of the natural
drainage of water from such property;
   (b)   Adversely affect adjacent private or public property by diversion of
surface water onto such adjacent property or by the increase in the rate of
run-off of surface water onto such adjacent property or by interference with,
or obstruction of, natural drainage of water from such adjacent property;
   (c)   Interfere with or obstruct the public water system or the public
sanitary or storm sewer system or interfere with or obstruct a natural
watercourse; or
   (d)   By reason of the type of fill material used or by the number of
fillings, create a nuisance by permitting such material or polluting effluent
therefrom to flow or be washed or drained onto adjacent private or public
property, or into a natural watercourse, or into the public water system, or
into the public sanitary or storm sewer systems. (Ord. 1973-75. Passed 4-10-
73.)
1337.03 ELEVATION CHANGES; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall, except pursuant to a permit issued by the Building
Inspector in accordance with the provisions of this chapter:
   (a)   Change by more than two inches the average elevation of any portion of
a lot or parcel of land within the City which lies within ten feet of any
boundary line thereof, each portion lying between each boundary line and a line
within such lot or parcel which is parallel to such boundary line being
considered a separate portion for the purposes of this subsection; or
   (b)   By filling or other means add soil or other surface material to any
lot or parcel of land within the City, or by excavation or other means remove
soil or other surface material from any such lot or parcel, in an amount
greater than one cubic yard for each 2,000 square feet of the total area of
such lot or parcel.
      (Ord. 1973-75. Passed 4-10-73.)
1337.04 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE.
   Whoever desires a permit in order to change the grade of any lot or parcel
of land within the City shall apply to the Building and Zoning Director, using
an application form furnished by the Director, and shall pay a nonrefundable
fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus an additional amount of
five dollars ($5.00) for each 1,000 square feet of the total area of the lot or
parcel for which the grade permit is requested in order to defray the cost of
City inspection. (Ord. 1994-3. Passed 2-22-94.)
1337.05 INSPECTION, REPORT AND CERTIFICATION BY CITY ENGINEER.
   The application for the permit required by Section
1337.03 shall be referred to the City Engineer who shall make an inspection of
the property and report to the Building Inspector. No permit shall be issued
unless the City Engineer finds and so reports to the Building Inspector that
the proposed change in grade, with such provisions for drainage and such
drainage facilities as the applicant proposes in connection therewith, will not
violate Section
1337.02.
   Upon issuance of such a permit, and following the completion of such change
in grade, the City Engineer shall certify to the Building Inspector that the
change in grade has been completed in accordance with the permit. (Ord. 1973-
75. Passed 4-10-73.)
1337.06 MAINTAINING GRADE LINES ESTABLISHED BY CITY.
   When the City Engineer has set and finally determined and established the
finished grade line of any parcel of real estate, lot or parcel of land within
the City, thus providing for the drainage of surface water therefrom, the
owner, occupant or any other person in charge of the premises shall continue to
maintain and adhere to the finished grade line of the premises and shall
further keep all drains, ditches, swales or other surface water conductors
open, free and clear of any and all obstructions.
(Ord. 1973-75. Passed 4-10-73.)
1337.07 USE OF FOUNDRY SAND AS LAND FILL.
   Any person desiring to utilize foundry sand or any foundry sand byproduct as
fill material shall, in addition to compliance with all other requirements of
this chapter, comply with the following conditions:
   (a)   Such person shall furnish a sketch of the area to be filled by the
deposit of foundry sand or foundry sand by products with accurate measurements
shown thereon as to the size of the area and the depth to be filled.
   (b)   The sketch shall designate the accurate location of any natural
watercourse or lake in the immediate area to be filled.
   (c)   A projected time schedule for filling such area, with proposed
safeguards to prevent foundry sand from blowing onto adjacent properties, shall
be submitted.
   (d)   The deposited foundry sand or foundry sand byproducts shall be
monitored by a reputable testing laboratory every six months, and a written
report shall be sent to the City Engineer, in order to determine whether or not
the deposit of such sand has an adverse effect on the adjacent area.
   (e)   There shall be no stockpiling of any foundry sand or foundry sand
byproducts, nor shall any unfired foundry sand be deposited for use as land
fill.
(Ord. 1979-43. Passed 3-27-79.)
1337.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, being the owner, lessee or occupant of property within the City
or the contractor under contract with any such person, who violates any
provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.   
(Ord. 1973-75. Passed 4-10-73.)
CHAPTER 1339
Heat in Rental Dwellings
1339.01   Minimum inside temperature.
1339.02   Location of heating equipment.
1339.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Venting of heaters and burners - see GEN. OFF.
660.01 
      Tourist cabins - see BUS. REG. Ch. 717
      Heating fee schedule - see BLDG.
1303.09
1339.01 MINIMUM INSIDE TEMPERATURE.
   The owner, operator or agent in charge of a dwelling structure who rents or
leases any dwelling unit therein under an agreement, express or implied, to
supply or furnish heat to the occupants thereof, shall supply heat adequate to
maintain in inside temperature of not less than seventy degrees Fahrenheit in
all habitable rooms, bathrooms, water closet compartments and kitchens whenever
the outside temperature falls below fifty degrees Fahrenheit. Such inside
temperature shall be measured in the approximate center of each room,
approximately three feet above the floor. The provisions of this section shall
not apply where the failure to meet minimum standards is caused by a general
shortage of fuel, a negligent or malicious act of the occupant or any cause
beyond the control of the owner or occupant.
(Ord. 1971-37. Passed 2-23-71.)
1339.02 LOCATION OF HEATING EQUIPMENT.
   No heating equipment, including water heaters, which burns solid, liquid or
gaseous fuel shall be located in any bedroom, bathroom, toilet room or any room
used for sleeping purposes, unless specifically approved for such location.
(Ord. 1971-37. Passed 2-23-71.)
1339.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1303.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

CHAPTER 1343

1343.01 EXTERIOR USE OF MASONRY BLOCK PROHIBITED.
   (a)   The use of masonry block, sometimes referred to as cinder block,
cement block or split face cement block, as a visible exterior construction
material in any building within the City, is hereby prohibited, unless the
material conforms to the Standard Specification for Facing Brick, C216-92d of
the American Institute for Testing and Materials, including any amendments
thereto, except that split face cement block is permitted in General Industrial
Districts.
   (b)   An addition to an existing building not conforming to subsection (a)
hereof may be constructed of the same nonconforming materials as the main
building if the Planning Commission determines that the addition would be more
consistent with the objectives of the Zoning Code if it is constructed of
nonconforming materials than it would be if it is constructed of conforming
materials.
(Ord. 1996-9. Passed 4-9-96.)
1343.02 FOUNDRY SAND FOR CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL PROHIBITED.
   The use of foundry sand or any foundry sand byproduct as a material for
construction, backfill for sidewalks, driveways, streets or lawns, or for
building foundations, is prohibited.
(Ord. 1979-42. Passed 3-27-79.)
1343.03 PLASTIC PIPE.
   (a)   The use of plastic pipe for the transmission of gas for service lines,
extending from the street curb to the dwelling only, is hereby permitted.
However, such use is subject to compliance with the provisions of "Standards
Set Forth for Gas Piping of Columbia Gas System," dated January 1, 1980, a copy
of which is attached to original Ordinance 1980-5, passed January 22, 1980, and
made a part hereof as though fully rewritten herein.
   (b)   The use of plastic lines (high-density polyethylene) for the
transmission of main gas lines in the street right of way is hereby permitted,
subject to compliance with the regulations enumerated in the "Standards Set
Forth for Gas Piping of Columbia Gas System," dated January 1, 1980, a copy of
which is attached to original Ordinance 1981-117, passed September 8, 1981, and
made a part hereof as though fully rewritten herein.
(Ord. 1981-117. Passed 9-8-81.)
1343.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1303.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

CHAPTER 1347
Landscaping and Lawn Services
1347.01   Definitions.
1347.02   License and bond required.
1347.03   Application and bond requirements; fee.
1347.04   Inspection and enforcement.
1347.05   Finished side of fencing to face abutting property.

   CROSS REFERENCES
      Grading and seeding lands allocated for public use - see P. & Z.

1347.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Landscaping" means the planning and the planting of trees, shrubs,
flowers, bulbs and other plants for the purpose of beautifying the premises,
not involving grading or drainage of a lot.
   (b)   "Lawn services" means the grading, application of fertilizers and
topsoil, installation of lawn sod and the seeding of lawns, not involving
grading or drainage of a lot. (Ord. 1973-158. Passed 8-14-73.)
1347.02 LICENSE AND BOND REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall contract, either orally or in writing, for the
planning, planting, sale and/or installation of trees, shrubs, flowers, bulbs,
lawns, grasses, groundcovers and the like, involving the grading or drainage of
a lot, without first obtaining a license, providing a cash bond for each and
every lot which will be the subject of the landscapers' activity, in the amount
of one hundred dollars ($100.00), and paying the fees provided herein. The cash
bond shall be refunded thirty days following inspection by the Building and
Zoning Director and his finding that the installation of the landscaping
facilities is satisfactory.
   (b)   No occupancy permit shall be issued unless one of the two following
conditions has been satisfied:
      (1)   The landscaping facilities have been installed according to the
landscape plan.
      (2)   A cash bond has been submitted to the Building Department, in an
amount which the City Planner determines to be sufficient, to insure completion
of any uncompleted portion of the landscape plan.
   (c)   In the event the landscaping plan is not completed within the time
provided by the Building and Zoning Director or the Planning Commission, such
bond shall be forfeited and applied toward the cost of installing or finishing
said landscape plan. In the event that the landscaping is completed according
to plan within the allotted time, the cash bond will be refunded. (Ord. 1989-
131. Passed 12-26-89.)
1347.03 APPLICATION AND BOND REQUIREMENTS; FEE.
   (a)   The application shall contain the name, address and principal place of
business or office of the applicant, together with a statement as to the length
of time he has been in business and his general experience or knowledge.
   (b)   The license shall be in force for a period of one year, and the fee
shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00).
   (c)   Each applicant shall provide an approved fidelity bond in the
principal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000) in favor of the City, for the
benefit of any person damaged by the dishonest, incompetent or fraudulent acts
of the applicant. Such bond shall be maintained in full force in the principal
amount at all times and shall provide that it shall not be cancelled or revoked
until ten days after written notice of intention to cancel or revoke has been
given to the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 1983-47. Passed 4-12-83.)
1347.04 INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The Engineer shall handle all matters regarding landscaping and lawn
services and installations and shall be responsible for the maintenance and
adherence by the landscaper to the grading or topographical plan for such lot
to be improved by landscaping. Such landscaper shall be required to maintain
the grade for any lot so improved by landscaping and shall also be required to
install such landscaping so as not to interfere with, obstruct or permit the
diversion of any surface waters with respect to such lot to the detriment of
any abutting or adjoining property owner's land. In the event such landscaping
does divert or obstruct surface waters or interfere with the grading or
topographical plan for such lot, such landscaper, upon receipt of written
notice by the Building Inspector, shall immediately commence to make the
necessary repairs or corrections in accordance with instructions from the
Engineer. Upon failure to so repair or correct such conditions, his bond shall
be forfeited forthwith.
   (b)   Upon a finding by the Engineer that any landscaping or lawn services
have not been installed according to contract, accepted nursery practices in
this region and the provisions set forth in subsection (a) hereof, the Engineer
shall so advise the Building Commissioner who may revoke the license issued
hereunder until the installation has been corrected in accordance with the
orders of the Engineer.
   (c)   Any license holder whose license has been revoked may appeal such
decision to the Mayor, by written notice of such intention to appeal filed
within ten days of the revocation of the license. The decision of the Mayor
shall be final.
(Ord. 1976-118. Passed 7-13-76.)
1347.05 FINISHED SIDE OF FENCING TO FACE ABUTTING PROPERTY.
   Whenever a fence is constructed within the City of Middleburg Heights, such
fence has one side which is more finished than the other side, the more
finished side shall face outside, and the less finished side shall face inside.
(Ord. 1990-4. Passed 1-9-90.)
1347.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1303.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1349
Flood Damage Reduction
   EDITOR’S NOTE: This chapter, previously a codification of Ordinance 1987-12,
passed March 10, 1987, was re-enacted in its entirety by Ordinance 1989-76,
passed August 8, 1989, and by Ordinance 2010-80, passed November 9, 2010.

   CROSS REFERENCES
      Flood control by soil conservation district supervisors - see Ohio R.C.
1515.08
      Flood insurance - see Ohio R.C. 3925.34(C), 3941.02(A)(1)
      Water supply, sanitation, ditches - see Ohio R.C. 6101.01 et seq.
      Altering, polluting and diverting watercourses - see GEN. OFF.
660.04
1349.01 FINDINGS OF FACT.
   The City of Middleburg Heights has special flood hazard areas that are
subject to periodic inundation which may result in loss of life and property,
health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services,
extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and
impairment of the tax base. Additionally, structures that are inadequately
elevated, flood proofed, or otherwise protected from flood damage also
contribute to the flood loss. In order to minimize the threat of such damages
and to achieve the purposes hereinafter set forth, these regulations are
adopted. (Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.02 STATEMENT OF PURPOSE.
   It is the purpose of these regulations to promote the public health, safety
and general welfare, and to:
   (a)   Protect human life and health;
   (b)   Minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control
projects;
   (c)   Minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with
flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public;
   (d)   Minimize prolonged business interruptions;
   (e)   Minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and
gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in
areas of special flood hazard;
   (f)   Help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the proper use and
development of areas of special flood hazard so as to protect property and
minimize future flood blight areas;
   (g)   Ensure that those who occupy the areas of special flood hazard assume
responsibility for their actions;
   (h)   Minimize the impact of development on adjacent properties within and
near flood prone areas;
   (i)   Ensure that the flood storage and conveyance functions of the
floodplain are maintained;
   (j)   Minimize the impact of development on the natural, beneficial values
of the floodplain;
   (k)   Prevent floodplain uses that are either hazardous or environmentally
incompatible; and
   (l)   Meet community participation requirements of the National Flood
Insurance Program. (Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-
10.)
1349.03 METHODS OF REDUCING FLOOD LOSS.
   In order to accomplish its pmposes, these regulations include methods and
provisions for:
   (a)   Restricting or prohibiting uses which are dangerous to health, safety,
and property due to water hazards, or which result in damaging increases in
flood heights or velocities;
   (b)   Requiring that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which
serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial
construction;
   (c)   Controlling the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels,
and natural protective barriers, which help accommodate or channel flood
waters;
   (d)   Controlling filling, grading, dredging, excavating, and other
development which may increase flood damage; and,
   (e)   Preventing or regulating the construction of flood barriers, which
will unnaturally divert flood-waters or which may increase flood hazards in
other areas.
      (Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.04 LANDS TO WHICH THESE REGULATIONS APPLY.
   These regulations shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within
the jurisdiction of the City of Middleburg Heights as identified in Section
1349.05, including any additional areas of special flood hazard annexed by City
of Middleburg Heights.
(Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.05 BASIS FOR ESTABLISHING THE AREAS OF SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD.
   For the purposes of these regulations, the following studies and/or maps are
adopted:
   (a)   Flood Insurance Study Cuyahoga County, Ohio and Incorporated Areas and
Flood Insurance Rate Map Cuyahoga County, Ohio and Incorporated Areas both
effective December 3, 2010.
   (b)   Other studies and/or maps, which may be relied upon for establishment
of the flood protection elevation, delineation of the 100-year floodplain,
floodways or delineation of other areas of special flood hazard.
   (c)   Any hydrologic and hydraulic engineering analysis authored by a
registered Professional Engineer in the State of Ohio which has been approved
by the City of Middleburg Heights as required by Section
1349.23(c) Subdivisions and Large Developments.
   Any revisions to the aforementioned maps and/or studies are hereby adopted
by reference and declared to be a part of these regulations. Such maps and/or
studies are on file at the City Hall at 15700 Bagley Road, Middleburg Heights,
Ohio.
(Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.06 ABROGATION AND GREATER RESTRICTIONS.
   These regulations are not intended to repeal any existing ordinances
including subdivision regulations, zoning or building codes. In the event of a
conflict between these regulations and any other ordinance, the more
restrictive shall be followed. These regulations shall not impair any deed
restriction, covenant or easement but the land subject to such interests shall
also be governed by the regulations.
(Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.07 INTERPRETATION.
   In the interpretation and application of these regulations, all provisions
shall be:
   (a)   Considered as minimum requirements;
   (b)   Liberally construed in favor of the governing body; and,
   (c)   Deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under
state statutes.
   Where a provision of these regulations may be in conflict with a state or
Federal law, such state or Federal law shall take precedence over these
regulations.
(Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.08 WARNING AND DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY.
   The degree of flood protection required by these regulations is considered
reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering
considerations. Larger floods can and will occur on rare occasions. Flood
heights may be increased by man-made or natural causes. These regulations do
not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazard or uses permitted
within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damage. These regulations
shall not create liability on the part of the City of Middleburg Heights, any
officer or employee thereof, or the Federal Emergency Management Agency, for
any flood damage that results from reliance on these regulations or any
administrative decision lawfully made thereunder.
(Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.09 SEVERABILITY.
   Should any section or provision of these regulations be declared by the
courts to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the
validity of the regulations as a whole, or any part thereof other than the part
so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid.
(Ord. 2010-63. Passed 9-28-10; Ord. 2010-80. Passed 11-9-10.)
1349.10 DEFINITIONS
   Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in these
regulations shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in
common usage and to give these regulations the most reasonable application.
   (1)   Accessory Structure.
      A structure on the same lot with, and of a nature customarily incidental
and subordinate to, the principal structure.
   (2)   Appeal.
      A request for review of the Floodplain Administrator's interpretation of
any provision of these regulations or a request for a variance.
   (3)   Base Flood.
      The flood having a one percent (1%) chance of being equaled or exceeded
in any given year. The base flood may also be referred to as the one percent
(1%) chance annual flood or one-hundred (100) year flood.
   (4)   Base (100-Year) Flood Elevation (BFE).
      The water surface elevation of the base flood in relation to a specified
datum, usually the National Geodetic Vertical Datum of 1929 or the North
American Vertical Datum of 1988, and usually expressed in Feet Mean Sea Level
(MSL). In Zone AO areas, the base flood elevation is the natural grade
elevation plus the depth number (from 1 to 3 feet).
   (5)   Basement.
      Any area of the building having its floor sub grade (below ground level)
on all sides.
   (6)   Development.
      Any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including but
not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling,
grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations or storage of equipment or
materials.
   (7)   Enclosure Below the Lowest Floor.
      See "Lowest Floor."
   (8)   Executive Order 11988 (Floodplain Management).
      Issued by President Carter in 1977, this order requires that no federally
assisted activities be conducted in or have the potential to affect identified
special flood hazard areas, unless there is no practicable alternative.
   (9)   Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).
      The agency with the overall responsibility for administering the National
Flood Insurance Program.
   (10)   Fill.
      A deposit of earth material placed by artificial means.
   (11)   Flood or Flooding.
      A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of
normally dry land areas from:
      A.   The overflow of inland or tidal waters, and/or
      B.   The unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from
any source.
   (12)   Flood Hazard Boundary Map (FHBM).   
      Usually the initial map, produced by the Federal Emergency Management
Agency, or U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, for a community
depicting approximate special flood hazard areas.
   (13)   Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM).
      An official map on which the Federal Emergency Management Agency or the
U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development has delineated the areas of
special flood hazard.
   (14)   Flood Insurance Risk Zones.
      Zone designations on FHBMs and FIRMs that indicate the magnitude of the
flood hazard in specific areas of a community. Following are the zone
definitions:
      A.   Zone A:
         Special flood hazard areas inundated by the 100-year flood; base flood
elevations are not determined.
      B.   Zones A1-30 and Zone AE:
         Special flood hazard areas inundated by the 100-year flood; base flood
elevations are determined.
      C.   Zone AO:
         Special flood hazard areas inundated by the 100-year flood; with flood
depths of 1 to 3 feet (usually sheet flow on sloping terrain); average depths
are determined.
      D.   Zone AH:
         Special flood hazard areas inundated by the 100-year flood; flood
depths of 1 to 3 feet (usually areas of ponding); base flood elevations are
determined.
      E.   Zone A99:
         Special flood hazard areas inundated by the 100-year flood to be
protected from the 100-year flood by a Federal flood protection system under
construction; no base flood elevations are determined.
      F.   Zone B and Zone X (shaded):
         Areas of 500-year flood; areas subject to the 100-year flood with
average depths of less than 1 foot or with contributing drainage area less than
1 square mile; and areas protected by levees from the base flood.
      G.   Zone C and Zone X (unshaded): Areas determined to be outside the
500-year floodplain.
   (15)   Flood Insurance Study (FIS).
      The official report in which the Federal Emergency Management Agency or
the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development has provided flood
profiles, floodway boundaries (sometimes shown on Flood Boundary and Floodway
Maps), and the water surface elevations of the base flood.
   (16)   Flood Protection Elevation.
      The Flood Protection Elevation, or FPE, is the base flood elevation. In
areas where no base flood elevations exist from any authoritative source, the
flood protection elevation can be historical flood elevations, or base flood
elevations determined and/or approved by the Floodplain Administrator.
   (17)   Floodway:
      A floodway is the channel of a river or other watercourse and the
adjacent land areas that have been reserved in order to pass the base flood
discharge. A floodway is typically determined through a hydraulic and
hydrologic engineering analysis such that the cumulative increase in the water
surface elevation of the base flood discharge is no more than a designated
height. In no case shall the designated height be more than one foot at any
point within the community.
      The floodway is an extremely hazardous area, and is usually characterized
by any of the following: Moderate to high velocity flood waters, high potential
for debris and projectile impacts, and moderate to high erosion forces.
   (18)   Freeboard.
      A factor of safety usually expressed in feet above a flood level for the
purposes of floodplain management. Freeboard tends to compensate for the many
unknown factors that could contribute to flood heights greater than the height
calculated for a selected size flood and floodway conditions, such as wave
action, obstructed bridge openings, debris and ice jams, and the hydrologic
effect of urbanization in a watershed.
   (19)   Historic structure:
      Any structure that is:
      A.   Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a
listing maintained by the U.S. Department of Interior) or preliminarily
determined by the Secretary of the Interior as meeting the requirements for
individual listings on the National Register;
      B.   Certified or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the
Interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered
historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the Secretary to
qualify as a registered historic district; or
      C.   Individually listed on the State of Ohio's inventory of historic
places maintained by the Ohio Historic Preservation Office.
   (20)   Hydrologic and hydraulic engineering analysis.
      An analysis performed by a professional engineer, registered in the State
of Ohio, in accordance with standard engineering practices as accepted by FEMA,
used to determine flood elevations and/or floodway boundaries.
   (21)   Letter of Map Change (LOMC).
      A Letter of Map Change is an official FEMA determination, by letter, to
amend or revise effective Flood Insurance Rate Maps, Flood Boundary and
Floodway Maps, and Flood Insurance Studies. LOMCs are broken down into the
following categories:
      A.   Letter of Map Amendment (LOMA)
         A revision based on technical data showing that a property was
incorrectly included in a designated special flood hazard area. A LOMA amends
the current effective Flood Insurance Rate Map and establishes that a specific
property is not located in a special flood hazard area.
      B.   Letter of Map Revision (LOMR)
         A revision based on technical data that, usually due to manmade
changes, shows changes to flood zones, flood elevations, floodplain and
floodway delineations, and planimetric features. One common type of LOMR, a
LOMR-F, is a determination concerning whether a structure or parcel has been
